Aroma is that of caramel and maple. The head is light brown and disappearance happen at a medium rate. The color is a deep, dark wood brown. Heavy, pleasant malt taste with a roasted aftertaste.

.33L Grolsch style flip top bottle served in a 22oz. snifter.

A - Pours a cloudy and very dark brown, with a pinkish tanned head, spotted lacing left behind.

S - Rich caramel malt, vanilla wood, caramelized brown sugar, dates, sugary brown cake, sweet short bread, cocoa sweet alcohol vapors.

T - Maple syrup right off the top, dense caramel malt, heavy sugary dates, toasty, sweet date bread, caramelized/burnt brown sugar, toasted marshmallow sweetness. Finishes bold with lingering alcohol.

M - Syrupy, silky feel, medium bodied, low carbonation.

WOW! Words cannot describe the aroma of this beer. This is a malt lovers dream come true. Very complex layers that meld wonderfully. Good alcohol presents that fits perfectly in with the rest of the flavors.

Serving type: bottle

03-30-2012
Amber doby with a fraothy off-white head. Aroma is caramel, flavour too. Malty sweet, maybe too much sweet, oily body. Interesting brew

Bottle. Pours a murky brown orange color with some layers of sediment. Bubbly head. Aroma is light, malty, light banana and yeast. Flavor is dry, woody, clay, yeasty with a very dry finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Swing top bottle. A clear dark brown beer, with a large, frothy, lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. The aroma is moderately malty (toasted/roasted bread/nuts, caramel, hint of chocolate), lightly hoppy (flowers), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of raisin, figs, grapes, plums, spices, some minor notes of medicine/syrup, smoke and alcohol. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, very long finish with moderate to heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Yes, very little of an Alt, many more resemblances to a Barley Wine, and not only an English one, given the nice and pretty abundant hopping. Good balance, creativity and complexity make this beer one of tyhe best from that area.

330 ml bottle from a friend - thanks Samuli. Hazy reddish brown colour, thin light beige head. Sweetish malty aroma with dates, plums, notes of yeast and berries. The flavour is roasted malty, with some caramel sweetness, dark fruits and a finish of herbal hops and a little warming alcohol. Very interensting and enjoyable.

Bottle (330 ml). Murky brown with a small beige head and almost no lacing. Aroma is rich and malty with caramel, dark fruits, peated notes, liquorice and herbal notes. Taste is moderately sweet with a lot of malt, caramel, raisins, liquorice, herbal presence and peated notes. Medium to full body. Good beer!

Cor marrom escura. Espuma creme com medis formação e persistência. Aroma de caramelo, frutas secas, malte. No sabor, açúcar mascavo, alto dulçor, baixo amargor. Teor alcoólico se sobressai no final. Boa cerveja. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark brown with a thin head. Aroma is yeast with a heavy dose of fruity malts. Flavour is dark fruit, cloying roasted malt on a syrupy base. Finish is dark dry malt
Pours brown and very hazy with light brown head. Aroma is roasted, sweet, caramel, cocoa and berries. Flavour is bitter, roasted, sweet and dry hoppy. Somewhat oily and medium-carbonated.

33 cl swing top bottle @ home. Pours hazy brown amber with an off-white head that leaves no lacing. Aroma is vinous, malt, and dark fruits. Flavour is sweet with caramel, malt, and some warming alcohol.

Bottle. Brown with reddish tones, slight haze. Nose is very deep malty, with vinous tones almost. Dark fruits, some ripe plums. A bit of roasty malts. Body is soft, full. A bit of sweetness, in a syrupy way. Bitter with a slightly dry finish. Really flavourful one, but more of a strong ale / barley wine than alt. The finish lingers on forever.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2013 Trade with Culchiem. Thanks. Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Very malty and yeasty. Dark fruit, sugars, rye and hops. Warmth. A close to a mess really. Too yeasty. Full bodied.
Re-rate Odense Juni 13. Liquorice, chocolate, caramel. Vinous. Alcohol note. Less of a mess - less yeast. 3,5-3,6.

Pretty sure this was barleywine...I had a special release that was 2008, so aged a while...was good but I think I would like it better fresh.  Smooth, sweet, with an oaky note on top of the sugar and dark fruit.  Very drinkable.  I could tell it was well crafted beer.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on April 4th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a brown cloud.
Aroma: Aroma of light caramel.
Taste: Mostly sweet taste, some caramel
Palate:Light body.
Summary: This bottle is decently old, Im looking forward to comparing it to the fresher one I have.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2013 from bottle. pours a dark hazy amber/brown colour and a small frothy beige head. complex aroma of burned sugar, malt, incense sticks, dark fruits, (raisins, plums, cranberries, black cherries etc.) and hints of vanilla and honey. full body, creamy mouthfeel and rather low carbonation. sweet malty and fruity flavours transform into a surprisingly hoppy bitter finish. an interesting alt variant that is full of character, which is, however, hard to capture...I definitely have to check it out again in order to rate it appropriately, particularly the taste.
Angenehm süslicher Duft. Gehaltvoll, feinperlende Rezenz. Feinherb im Nachklang

Pours deep brown/black with a stately, light brown head.
Aroma is chocolate malt, dark, fresh bread.
Taste is woody, malty, earthy hops,ovveripe fruits, vanilla.
Strong boozy aspect.
Slight cheesy-funk.
Odd, and interesting.

På flaska, bortglömd i en amerikansk bar. Därmed lagrad i ett par år. Mörkt brun öl med ett lätt smutsvitt skum. Doft av mörkt bröd, maltsirap och russin. Även smaken är ganska söt med karamell och russin. Ölet börjar få portvinslika kvaliteer. Lätt nötig, träig beska.

500 mL bottle from Beer Revolution in Oakland.  Red-brown with a bubbly head.  Gorgeous chocolate malt aroma with some caramel candi. Sweet, very sweet and creamy.  Much lighter and soft drink than I was expecting.  Sweet, chocolately and interesting - but also odd.  A bit of a cross between soup and dessert.  Not as good as Id hoped but interesting.

Nose that has the character of barleywine crossed with cream and seltzer. Brown and clear. Vanilla. Butter tart and raisiny sourness. Nose and flavour translate well together. Toasty. Sweet and sour finish similar to a scotch ale.

Dunkelbraun, fast schwarz, leicht trüb, kleine Schaumcrema. Wunderbare Aromenvielfalt: Portweinartig fruchtig und schwer, eingelegte Rosinen, Pflaume, Hefe, Tabak, Sandelholz.  Sirupartige Textur. Startet fulminant herb, geht dann über in eine Würze nach Röst- und Karamellmalz mit Zartbitter. Hohe Aromendichte, sehr komplexer Nektar, der noch ein paar Ecken und Kanten aufweist, die bei längerer Lagerung wohl runder werden dürften. Ein Juwel deutscher Braukunst, ganz großes Kino.

Bottled on 5/11, had 2/13. Pours a dark dense brown with a thin eggshell cream. Nutty rich slightly sweet, toasted musty barley bread aroma. The flavors is sweet barley and a wooden nutty character. The earthy spicy German hops pair uniquely with the sweet roasted barley and a wooden nutty grain. Modestly complex, fairly easy to drink, probably not easily accessible for many peoples palates. A drying nutty finish with earthy grains lingers with a fair amount of sweetness, a unique German barleywine is a decent label, it is close to the j.w.Lees harvest in grain and hop flavors but the yeast spins it just enough to change it.

Jolie bouteille de 330 ml, avec bouchon de céramique, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de caramel avec une pointe dagrumes. Apparence: La couleur est brune foncée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel légèrement brûlé avec une pointe fruitée. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #4538)

Dark brown, thin white head. Big sweet malts and hops in nose. Sweet malty taste, like a doppelbock. Chocolate, wood, vanilla. Boozy finish. As it warms up the booze and sweetness take over excessively.

This was a nice mix up of flavors. Tons of citrusy hop aromas, grapefruit, and some nice caramel and fruitiness. Very rich aroma. The flavor is similar with a heavy hop presence. Tons of grapefruit, some pine, and caramel and light roast. Very complex, similar to arrogant bastard for me.

A hazy brown, burnt caramel appearance, lots of floaties. Weakly carbonated so not much head but swirling the glass gives it a nice sticky coating. Molasses, fig, caramel, almond on the nose. Taste has more light coffee tones of bitterness, with some of the almond and licorice coming through as well. Seems boozy even though it is only 8.5 ABV. Full bodied, silky mouthfeel. Excellent.

This was a heavy, fruity, sticky German beer. Lots of sweet caramel malts and sugary fruit in the mix with a hint of hops. It tasted very sweet and a tad grassy with a lingering toffee aftertaste. This is a beer that would be phenomenal as a vintage. Ill be looking for this one later.

Rich, syrupy with notes of dark dried fruit and sweet malt balanced with just enough hops and alcohol to keep it from being cloying. This is worth seeking out and maybe cellaring for a year or to just for kicks.

The initial taste is that of licorice and rye, which transitions to peppery mocha. Then there comes the bitterness that lays on the tongue. The final layer of taste is a lasting malty imprint of prune-fig. The color is a sierra brown with some grey & weak head- low carbonation.  The aroma is alcohol/prune. The mouthfeel is similar to barleywine, very thick- but with such intricate flavor, one does not notice a syrupy overtone. Very interesting and unique.

Dark copper/red with a small whitish head. Complex malty aromas that includes caramel, hazelnut  and a strong dark cherries presence. Full bodied, very classy malts, hints of bitterness in the back of the tongue all wrapped up in this multi layered malt bed. Very nice and classic alt.

Flip top bottle. Pours a thick dark mahogany brown with no head. Aroma of caramel malt, some dark dried fruit esters, brown sugar, yeast and bready notes fill the senses. Taste same as aroma with some sweet liquorices flavor, alcohol and mild bitter notes. Palate is a full body, sweet thick sticky mouth feel, mild carbonation. Finish is sweet caramel malt, very yeasty and bread, with some dark fruit, brown sugar, ending with a dry boozy lingering sweet bitter liquorices flavor. Overall a good strong flavorful brew.

Bottle. Pours clear dark mahogany, large creamy tan head that dissipates slowly with nice lacing. Aroma is molasses, caramel, nutty, chocolate, dried fruit. Rich and complex. Flavor is about the same, quite sweet and rich with a light tart finish. Full bodied and creamy in the mouth; overall a nice beer.
Beautiful. Huge maltiness in aroma and flavor. Superb mouthfeel, and bittering hops on the end. Well deserving of its rating. Tasted at 65F.

2008 Vintage: Pours a murky dark brown. A fine off white ring of bubbles is as close to a head as its going to get. Smells of ripe dark fruits and toffee with an earthy spice. Much more complex in the flavor. The standard barley wine flavor is a backdrop for spicy, grassy hops and candied fruit. Hop bitterness at the end keeps it crisp even after 4 years. Clean mouthfeel with only a slight sticky film left on the lips. This is way under done in the beer world. Very, very good!

Older bottle but cant quite make out the date on the label.  Nice deep red color, no head to speak of.  Quite malty nose, a bit stale smelling.  Taste reminds me of a barley wine past its prime; flat and sticky and alcoholic.  Hops and malt do play well together but there is just too much history on this beer to do it justice.

Bottle 33cl, kindly donated by Simon (cave à bulle). A dark beer with good creamy head. Nose is powerful, caramel, dark malt, dark chocolate, light smoked notes with wood / sour touch. Aroma is on soy sauce, burnt caramel, wood, light prune touch, relativity less sweet, red grapes, licorice, bitter, spicy, anise, gingerbread, nutty, complex. Good, a bit dry, anyway far from an altbier, near to eisbock profile.

Brown bottle, 11,2 ounces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on October 30 2012; eye: dirty brown with coppery reflections, hazy, tiry ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: malt, alcohol, candied fruits, caramel, light roasted barley; mouth: intense, malt, alcohol, light candied fruits, caramel, alcohol, alcohol warmth, roasted barley, light hops hiding under the alcohol, finale in alcohol with presence of roasted barley, medium-full body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, alcoholic texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 11,2 onces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 30 octobre 2012; il : brun sale avec des reflets cuivrées, trouble, petit anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : malt, alcool, fruits confits, caramel, léger orge torréfiée; bouche : intense, malt, alcool, léger fruits confits, caramel, alcool, chaleur dalcool, orge torréfiée, léger houblon se cachant sous lalcool, finale en alcool avec présence dorge torréfiée, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture alcoolique; en résumé : bien

Swing-top bottle (33 cl) from bierundbier.de. Shady copper, medium beige head. Intense caramelly and nutty malt aroma with notes of red berries and dried fruits; herbal and grassy hops. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Semi sweet, intense and lingering bitterness. Really good stuff.

330ml bottle.  Pours coppery amber color, with a creamy off white head, that leaves some lacing.  The aroma was floral and fruity with a strong flowery presence coupled with a slight alcohol phenolic spice and some nice caramel maltiness.  Taste starts out with a caramal maltiness, some dark fruit flavors come through briefly, before a nice hit of grassy hops that leave a slightly lingering bitterness which mixes with the alcohol taste as the beer warms. Mouthfeel is somewhat creamy, and dispite the big sweetness, isnt at all syrupy.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours dark opaque brown with small off-white head.  Thin small bubble lacing, thick chewy body, low carbonation, and dark fruit aroma.  Taste is nuts, dark fruit, and a hint of alcohol.  Pretty heavy, I like lighter alts.

(33 cl swingtop bottle) chestnut-coloured, hazy with some sediment, big tan head with a greenish hue. Very intense, dominated by a resinous/sandalwood aroma that seems to be typical of Uerige beers, since I also find it in their Sticke and Alt. It is accompanied by notes of dark dried fruits and toffee smells very much  of oily hops . Taste is heavily sweet at first, with a medium bitterness coming through slowly, but persistently. Full-bodied, sticky texture, with a long finish. A remarkable beer that does not resemble anything else I have had (except the Sticke and the Alt, of course). However, the intensity and sticky sweetness make it less easily drinkable than the lighter versions by the same brewery. I am still curious to see if it will age well.... to be continued!

Bottle from Knightly. Pours a murky brown with a bubbly white head that fades fast and laces a little. Aroma of deep, rich roasted malts, toffee, caramelized brown sugar, toasted almonds with a bit of earthiness. Sweet creamy brown sugar up front, anise seed, black licorice with more toffee and toasted almonds. Huge creamy body with modest carbonation. Very layered and complex beer. Damn good.

11.2 oz swingtop bottle. Pours muddy brown with no head and a small beige ring of foam that fades after awhile--uuuggly. Aroma is over-the-top (for me) maltiness--lots of caramel here; also, some oxidation. Taste is overly malty sweet with a lingering bitter hop finish. Dark fruits mingle with caramel sweetness in flavor. Nothing wrong with the palate, but nothing blowing my mind, either. I bought this because its the highest rated altbier, but I dont think these malty styles, and this style in particular, will ever be a favorite of mine.

Bottle. Thanks Nightfall. Pours lovely, deep, brown with a small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has lots of sweet caramel, deep milky chocolate. Almost some Werthers Echte, but in a very good way. Medium carbonation, super creamy and quite dry mouthfeel. Flavour is lovely, even if the alcohol is a bit prominent. Fat caramel, sweet chocolate, hazelnuts, walnuts. Also a fine hint of blue grapes.

330ml bottle. Minimally cloudy, red glowing, dark amber colour with small, frothy, reawakening, minimally lacing, beige head. Caramel malty aroma, bitter hoppy overtones, hints of alcohol. Taste is bitter hoppy with heavy malt basis, some caramel, hints of dark chocolate, later also minimally roasty, bitter hoppy finish. Resembles a well-hopped Barleywine.

Drank at La Fête Bières & Saveurs de Chambly 2012, on September 2. Very muddy brown, thin head. Raw barley and sweet caramel aroma. Barley taste very sweet, good sensation of caramelized alcohol, sweet alcohol aftertaste. Altbier that gives a kick in the ass!

Une bouteille bue à lorée du bois.  Une robe brune, je suppose, et sa petite tête mousseuse.  Un nez bien intéressant par son aspect rassembleur : du caramel foncé avec une tonne de fruits confits (des raisins!) et des parfums de réglisse qui viennent se fondre dans lhabile combinaison menée par les houblons (herbes vertes?) et un alcool pratiquement floral.  Des saveurs réconfortantes.  Un vin fortifié par les fruits et par un alcool enrobant.  Des sucres maltés, des notes rôties et cette apparition houblonnée fraîche qui me plaît beaucoup.  Une apparition épicée ou une simple hallucination?  Un corps qui présente une rondeur de moyenne densité (ce qui augmente sa buvabilité) avec un pétillement très bas et une texture huileuse.  En finale, une lutte entre les houblons, lalcool et les malts rôtis.  Certainement une bière très complexe et vraiment succulente.

Bouteille à long cou de 330ml avec swing-top obtenue via IPB. Bière ambrée foncée presque brune un peu trouble. La mousse a une superbe circonstance. Le premier nez est fromagé, ensuite il y a une tonne de caramel et de fruits noires confits ou séchés. La bouche est sucrée, soutenue et ferme. Le caramel, les fruits, les houblons et le sucre sentremêlent. Une forte amertume complète le tout. Intéressant et différant. 7/10

sampled at bieres et saveur A: Licorice, dark caramel, spice, grapes App: hazy brown lasting white head.  T/p: full body  long sweet finish. Soft carbonation. O: amazing  for the sweet tooth ton of caramel with just a bitter touch to balance it all

330ml from IPB.
Appearance : Clear dark amber small head.

Aroma : Big rich sweet malt with resinous and slightly grassy hops. Lots of dark dried fruits. Caramel, toffee, light alcohol.

Taste : Rich malt with lots of hops. Quite resinous and bitter. Finish gets quite bitter and slightly astringent before some alcohol comes in and then more rich malt.

Palate : Carbonation is fairly soft. Big rich mouthfeel. Sweet finish with solid bitter backbone.

Overall : Interesting and quite tasty. Packed with flavor. A sipper for sure. I think this is missing some balance and harmony. The hoppyness is still fairly punchy... maybe this could benefit from a few months to a year of aging.  Feels a bit raw on the edges right now.
---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Swing top bottle, probably a year or so old. Murky dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is lots of dark fruit (raisins, prunes, ect.), toffee and some alcohol. Flavor is rich sweet toffee and caramel, doughy malt, light smoke and some alcohol warming. Medium to full body with mild carbonation. Very nice beer, like a sweet barley wine with a light smoky edge.
Dark amber color. Caramel and honey to the nose. Malty taste at first and it lingers until the hops kick at the end. Very enjoyable beer.

Cloudy deep reddish brown pour, thin ring of off white head .... Aroma of chewy caramel malts, and light spicy hops .... Taste is of chewy caramel malts, spicy bitter floral hops and bitter roasted malts ... Little warming and lingering dry roasted malts also a lasting bitter hop ... Very barleywine like abv hidden pretty well
Poured from a bottle thanks to Kevin. Very malty, spicy, earthy, leathery, licorice, slight hot alcohol. Very nice.
Looks like apple cider.  Taste is fruity and sticky.  Some apple quality to it.  No head with a full mouth.  Dried fruit and caramel apples come to mind.  Super sticky and sweet.
Clear dark cherry body with a small creamy head. Sweet molasses aroma with a malty hint. Sweet light honey flavor on a dark misty background.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of sweet raisins, roasted malts and some burnt notes. Flavour is quite heavy with notes of roasted malts, sweet raisins, bitter hops, loads of heavy caramel, licorice and dark chocolate. Some interesting peppery spicy notes after few sips. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a long, warming, deep finish with loads of flavour. Quite complex and very enjoyable.

330ml bottle pours a dark amber brown color with a small white head that leaves almost no lacing on the glass.  Aroma is caramel and light roasted grains with some dark fruits.  Taste is bold malty sweetness with some dark fruits and light hop bitterness.  Medium to heavy body with mild carbonation.  Very strong sweet tasting beer that is quite interesting.

Bottle.
Dark brown containing some red, with a porous beige head.
Aroma: fruity, malty, vanilla, dried tropical fruits.
Taste: malty, earthy, floral, pepper, licorice, dried fruits, medium bitter.
Medium to full-bodied.
Very nice.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle bought in Ocaña (Toledo, Spain). It pours a dark, reddish brown color with a very thin top for a head. The head dissipates very quickly to a thin ring around the edge of the glass. The nose is very malty and the association with a barley wine isnt off. Malty with dark fruit notes and an obvious sweetness. The flavor is strikingly smooth but rich with notes of dark dried fruit, dark caramel, dark bread, and raisin. Very tasty. Rich in body with low carbonation leading to a medium, warm finish. This excellent brew is definitely worth trying.

What an odd beer. Nose is initially hop pungent, before becoming toffee malt heavy. Body has raisin, toffee, molasses, fig and licorice with a medium length, medium bitterness in the finish. A bit more body and this would be an absolute classic. Will age a bottle to see what happens, as I think this could get quite interesting...

Un verdadero descubrimiento. La mejor cerveza de Dusseldorf que he probado. Desde luego es una interpretación de una barley wine alemana; oscura, densa, sabrosa, con toques de frutos maduros y muy redonda en la boca. Una gran cerveza que lástima no encontrar más a menudo.
Es una de las mejores cervezas Alemanas que he probado. Color oscuro, con olor ahumado. Para los grados que tiene no sale el alcohol, sino un toque dulce/ahumado.

color marron con espuma poco persistente pero aguanta un rodal hasta el final. Aroma a maltas ahumadas. frutos secos como pasas y uvas. sabor sorprendente dulce con toques a lupulos, es una cerveza de gran complejidad con el alcohol perfectamente integrado y un retrogusto a lupulo perfecto.
Color marrón oscuro bien filtrada con espuma beige poco persistente. Aroma salado, me recuerda a jamón Serrano con pasas. Sabor muy parecido a las barley wine con final seco y amargo

Bottle.  Pours deep brown, nearly black, with a couple fingers of tan head and some sticky lacing.  Aroma is all malt, mostly roasted and some burn notes.  Taste is super malty with tons of caramel and a little chocolate followed by roastiness.  The palate is very full and a little sticky.  Overall, this is a killer beer.  Thanks to the guy at Whole Foods who recommended it to me.

March 2010: Tall thin brown flip-top bottle, poured twice into a Frankenheim Alt glass. First pour the beer was clear, second murky.

Deep, dark reddy brown body with a lovelly velvet/silky feeling tan coloured head.

The smell was of lighty burnt malts, with some harsh chocolate blocks added to take away the charcoal thoughts my nose began to get. The aroma sweetened as the beer warmed.

The malts fill your mouth with bitterness from the burnt aspect mentioned in the smell. The alcohol then burns into the tongue and the chocolate turns into a more bitter mouthfeel than it hinted in the aromas. This adds to the impression of the beer being really bitter, which it is at first, but as your mouth dries a warming richness arrives bringing a sweeter aftertaste.

I liked it a great deal and am very pleased to have at last tasted one of these beers.

hazy mahogany with a thin but lasting beige head. syrupy full body with medium carbonation.

aroma: rich dark bready malt, roasty malt, dark fruit and toasted marshmallow, mild alcohol notes. Complex and inviting.

taste: sweet caramel and chocolate malt, dark orange (grand marnier), and mild alcohol. has a very similar malt profile to good american barleywines.

a definite after-dinner sipper. would be great with some walnut or mushroom brie, or even a creamy bleu.

(33 cl bottle courtesy of rawalli, thanks! Bottled on: 02/06) The initial aroma coming from the swing-top bottle when opened (with a loud pop) is that of hops. Pleasant, herbal and brief. Once poured the beer reveals itself to be of a clear, dark brown variety with a medium, tan head that laces the glass heavily and shows decent retention. The aroma after pouring is different. There is a yeasty note with a faint sourness but I also detect aromas of herbal hops and some syrupy malt that does not dominate the aroma as it would do in for example a doppelbock. When tasting the beer it seems all the flavour ingredients are still present along with notes of dried fruit in an pleasant and smooth, amalgated form with not much of an alcohol bite. Texture is oily, carbonation is soft, body is full and the finish is slightly bitter with astringent notes. Very smooth and drinkable for a beer of this age. Girlfriend says: "It tastes weird."

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 Thanks John! 6 months old....pours cloudy cola color. Off white head. Smells  of rich malt, licorice, molasses. Taste has a lot of the deep malt, licorice and molasses. Rich and special...nice dry slightly bitter finish. Medium body slick and smooth. 

Update - Opened a 2.5 year old bottle on July 17. 2013. Similar taste profile but less hops and a more intense fruit, licorice, molasses flavor. Great stuff that hold up very well.

Aroma:  Sweet. Roasted caramel malts. Toffee and dark fruits. cookie dough, candy cane. Proportionate bittering hops, spicy and herbal. 

Appearance: Murky dark brown mahogany with one finger beige head. Head dissipates and leaves a liquor like oily top.

Taste: Sweet and warming. The alcohol is very present and the beer finishes nearly medicinal. Warming sugars and bready malts with a mint like presence.

Palate:  Full and sweet. Somewhat sticky and molasses like. Finishes strong and bitter.

Overall:  A nice powerful winter warmer. Save for cold weather and drink as an after-dinner beer.
Definitely worth drinking. Good German Style beer not heavy but a dark colored beer. Very light

Tap off a 5-year old keg @ E9, Dec 11. Opaque reddish-brown pour with a short tan head leaving minimal lace. Nose is dark fruit-sweet and earth. Medium-heavy body with light, fine carbonation. Dark fruit, band aid, herbs, blue cheese, bourbon - this is a strong-tasting, very strange altbier. I both loved and hated it alternately, all through several 4-oz glasses. The age of this keg and the extreme flavors and sourness makes me think this may not be a typical sample, but its extraordinary!
Pours dark redish brown with a finger of head. Strong aroma of figs, grapes, malt & yeast. Tastes amazing. Fruit, caramel, spices, malt, chocolate & alcohol. Cant wait to buy more.

0.33 l fliptop bottle (Thanks to Mantlesorrow!).
Reddish deep dark brown pour with a two finger thick beige head and sediments on the bottom.
Intensive tart, dried fruity smell.
Oily and moderate sticky mouthfeel with a liqueur/dried fruity tasted aroma escorted by caramel, chocolate and hops underpainted gently by licorice and some notes of alcohol.
The medium dry finish brings citrusses, spices and gently warming alcohol along, which leaves a long tart aftertaste behind.
Serious and complex rarity, which I was glad to taste

Location: 11.2 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 1/7/12


Aroma: The nose has some roast, bread, earth, caramel, and some other malts

Appearance: A dark brown-black pour with a light brown-beige head and spotty lace

Flavor: The taste is medium (plus) sweet, with a lot of malty flavors to it

Palate: The body is medium, with a touch on the sticky side, with a little bit of heat

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty interesting offering.  It has a pretty solid flavor, and a decent body,  I enjoyed trying this one.

330mL bottle, side-by-side with Sticke, pours a murky deep dark brown with some orange tints (darker than Sticke), with a small ring of beige head. Aroma is more like a barley wine, with rich notes of dark dried fruits, loads of caramel, toasted bread, toasted nuts, and lager yeast. Flavour is much richer than Sticke, tasting more like a barley wine, with rich sweet notes of toffee and caramel though not cloying at all, dark dried fruits (raisins, dates), some pomegranate, bready malts, molasses and some brown sugar. Much richer, sweeter and complex than Sticke. Delicious and worthy of its reputation.

Nice red-brown with tan head.  Aroma complex with brown sugary malt, bread, caramel, chocolate.  Medium-full body with a little alcohol.  Equally complex flavors which are mostly malty and background of dark fruits and molasses.  Some dryness on the finish but hops are not predominant.  Very nice.
Draft.  Clear dark brown color, tan edge head.  Aroma of boozy chocolate liqueur.  Taste is black bread, citrus, malt, subtle licorice.  Interesting.
Complex, pours medium with light head, lightly barley, maybe a bourbon taste, excellent after taste with a slight sour finish, very slight. Cheers!

Very cool, uniquely shaped bottle with a stopper top.  Aromas of dark fruit licorice, caramel, and some chocolate.  Appearance is like a stout or a Porter, but held up to a light you can see a ruby red hue and lots of suspended sediment.  Taste is thick and very malty, finishes a bit on the bitter side.

11.2oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours very deep brown with a thick, fluffy, cream-colored head.  Aroma of roasted and caramel malts, some doughy/cereal notes, and a decent amount of hops for a German beer.  Flavor a nice blend of everything.  Smooth texture.  One of Germanys best beers.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2016 Part II Revisited 12/16/16 Bottled in 2009
Pours a very dark brown, ruby color. Lots of thick yeasty chunks. No head in this bottle, possibly from the age. Aroma is of white cheddar, dark chocolate, caramel, candy sugar, dark stonefruit, ovaltine, and sorghum. Taste is of  caramel, candy sugar, chocolate, butterscotch, slight hop bitterness, alcohol, bread. Its a very heavy flavored beer, very thick, not in mouthfeel but in flavor. Mouthfeel is very, very nice. Fantastic beer, the aroma on this beer is my favorite thing about it. 
-------- off this beer is extremely complex, very huge.   This beer pours an amazing dark hazy red color with lots of chunks.  These chunks arent big but very small and distributed throughout the beer, not all settling at the bottom of the glass(by chunks I mean this beer is unfiltered)(as all beer should/shouldnt be?).  The aroma is of sweet malts with caramel notes, seemingly from the roasting, along with very light chocolate notes carrying a bit of bitter(haha).   Also has some sour notes at the very beginning of the beer.  Taste begins with a cherry note with a slight sour  note.  Turns into a very sweet malt note finishing with anise mixed with perhaps caramel.  There is a note or two that are funky and throwing me off.  Might have to come back to this one.  Great beer, just need to try it more than once to get it down to a science, fantastic.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2013 33 cl bottle, rated on 19.10.2010
Dark brown colour. Barley wine -like aroma has sweet malt and fruits. Flavour has alcohol and sweet malt, feels a bit like American ales. Good and somewhat unique!
8+4+7+4+15=3.8

33 cl bottle @ PBF VIII, BBE 01.04.2014
Aroma has sweet malty notes, caramel and toffee. Flavour has alcohol, harsh malt, caramel, toffee and distant grassy notes. Sweet of course but still as good.
8+4+7+4+15

Dark brown colour, beige head. Sweet malty aroma, raisins, madeira, caramel and dough. Flavour is sweet, malty, caramel light hops, spices, roasted malts and raisins. Finish is sweet with some bitter notes. Nice and quite special.
(From 33cL fliptop bottle @ DRBM)

Draught, 8.5%. Fat, creamy aroma with a hint of vanilla. Oxidised. Very dark brown colour, seems cloudy. Small creamy light brown head. The flavour is extremely creamy with some vanilla. Silky mouthfeel. Nasal vinous notes. Quite sweet, vanilla malt syrup finish. Atypical German beer.

Cools fliptop bottle from Beerman6686 
Appearance: Dark brown with a medium beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, sweet caramel and vanilla 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel of roasted malts, toffee and brown sugar 
Very good and easy drinking

50cl Bottle at DRBM. Dark brown colour, light beige head. Aroma is very sweet malty, raisins. Flavour is sweet, malty, raisins, grassy bitter finish with some alcohol, a bit sharp. Medium to fullbodied. Nice.
Quite dead, dark brown and no head. Raisin, grapes, dough and woody. Strong sweet and alcoholic, unrefined but tasty. (DRbM 2011)

Bottle @ drbm. Aroma is deep malty roasty caramel sugar madness.
Flavour is deep sugary malt, caramel, sugar, earth, spices.

Bottle.  Very dark brown/black pour, a little lacing and carbonation and an earthy leather and malt aroma.  Flavor is earthy figs, roasted nuts, plenty of roasted malt and a dry/hoppy and slightly boozy flavor on the finish.  Solid beer, and not unreasonable at $5/bottle.

Has a barley wine aroma but a bit sweeter.  The flavor is very malty with a bit of alcohol burn plus a noticeable graininess.  Pretty good, a good interpretation of a barley wine, with a German quality to it.

Funny shaped bottle.  Pretty sweet looking.  Pours a brown color with a light brown head.  Pretty foamy head.  Smells pretty sweet.  Also a little bready.  Taste is super sweet.  Sweet like cheesecake.  And i love cheesecake.  Little bitterness near the middle of the gulp.  Wooo.

Sampled on 9/24/2011. This altbier pours a slightly hazy medium dark amber brown color from a swing top 33cl bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head, with decent lacing. The aroma is caramel, brown sugar, molasses and sweet. A medium to full bodied albier. The malts are caramel, brown sugar, molasses and sweet. The hops are citrusy and herbal. Decent carbonation. Tastes more like a barleywine than an altbier. Nice malt sweetness balanced nicely by the hops. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Malzig-würziger Geruch, süßlich nach Anis und Süßholz. Antrunk süßmalzig. Mitte würzig mit Lakritz, beginnend bitter. Im Schluß dann wieder süßer, malzige Töne vermengt mit Anis und angenehm bitter. Überraschend milde Alkoholnote. 
Verdammt gut.Test vom 25.10.2010

Blainchards Liquors, Boston 11.2oz ($6): I have been waiting a long time to try this beer and now that I finally had a chance, it was pretty much what I expected. I think that the Sticke is probably one of the best beers ever made, and the doppel might be too much of  a good thing. Pours a brownish color with an off-white head. Aroma is a whole lot of malts, caramel, sugar, and a not negligible amount of hops. Taste is thick and not quite syrupy. It is plenty sweet, but the hops are present around the finish of this beer. The description claiming that this is like a German barley wine is pretty much spot on. Sticke is also really fun to say.

Pours a deep chestnut color with a medium tan head...ok lacing.  Aroma has fig and vanilla...slightly doughy.  Aroma displays slightly more vanilla and doughyness...also fig, other fruity notes, and faint earthy/spicy notes.  Very silky mouthfeel and a roasty, caramely finish that hangs around.

Uerige
Dopple Sticke
Pours  a medium brown with ruddy undertones. Light on the head, but long on the retention and mild lacing. Nice aroma of cinnamon apples and raisins with a nice malty undertones. Flavor is dark fruits with some apples and pears. Some booze notes and a nice malt backbone. Very yummy and I will do this again if I can get it. Mild bitterness at the finish (very mild).
Aromas of raisin, toffee and dark fruit.  Flavors brown sugar, raisin, and dark fruit.  Overall a great altbier.

Appearance: dark brown, short tan head, decent lace.  Aroma: very sweet, lots of raisin, booze, brown sugar, brown bread.   Taste: sweet, boozy, notes of raisin, port, brown sugar, molasses, caramel, brown bread, and a lot of really unpleasant medicine.  Finish: sticky, syrupy and very medicinal, with what I think is supposed to be piney hops.  Notes: Tasted like a doppelbock brewed with cough syrup.  I keep trying to find an altbier I like.  This aint it, which must be some kind of sacrilege, as I do understand the significance of this beer.  Could be that the alt style just isnt for me.

Bottle. Pours a dark ruby brown color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish malty molasses and caramel aroma with weak hints of hops. Sweetish malty bready molasses and caramel flavor with nutty hints. Has a sweetish malty nutty caramel finish. with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Hopfiger, etwas säuerlicher (dennoch sehr angenehmer) und überaus aromatischer Geruch, der allerdings nicht im Entferntesten an Altbier erinnert. Der Antrunk ist sehr (sehr!) würzig und tief malzern, was sich im Mittelteil noch etwas steigern kann. Hier zeigt sich eine leichte Alkoholnote, die nicht weiter stört, da süßlich überdeckt. Das Doppel Sticke bleibt im Abgang süß, ein herbes Aroma gesellt sich hinzu, wird durch die gleichzeitig aufkommende Hopfigkeit aber fast schon in den Hintergrund gedrängt.. Weiterhin ist das Bier sehr aromatisch und vollmundig, ich meine, eine dezente Honignote zu erkennen. Schön, dass auch deutsche solch ein komplexes und leckeres Bier brauen können, sonst muss man sich für solche Biere im Ausland bedienen (was ja leider auch bei diesem der Fall ist). 	 
Test vom 23.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 13,12,11,13,14,13 - 12,60

Bottle.  Pour is a deep brown and slightly murky.  A small off white head is present.  Aroma is sweet caramel and some toffee.  Taste is also sweet with caramel, roasted malts, raisins, and a slight citrus presence toward the finish.  The citrus gives way to a slight bitterness.  The bitterness does a good job of keeping this beer from getting too sweet for me.  Medium bodied.  Pretty good.

Purchased at Beers of the World in Rochester NY.  Pours a murky dark brown. aroma is very sweet; dried fruit, caramel and maybe a little licorice. Flavor basically the same as the aroma. Very sweet, but there is a nice bitterness to the finish that prevents it from being cloying. Good beer all around, glad I picked it up off the shelf.

Bottle from the Perfect Pour recommended by employee.  Pours dark brown with amber tint. Very sweet  Grain and malt aromas.  Sweet malt flavor.  Dried fruits and caramel flavors.  Some bitterness and alcohol in finish.

Tasty altbier that does its damndest to act like a Barleywine.  Big and thick and super-malty, yet with a bitter, European finish that keeps the brew from becoming a bottle of maple syrup.  Huge caramel and toffee malt meets with a tiny bit of dried fruit sweetness, but it grows dry and doughy before sliding into a boozy, bitter finish.  Good palate, good beer, great bottle.  (4/27/09)

First rating for an altbier (and the #1 in the world, according to RateBeer).  11.2 ounce cool flip-top bottle purchased a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($5.79).  Pours a dark copper-brown hue with two fingers of beige foam.  Aroma of dark fruit, molasses, caramel, earthy wood, and (strangely) salty sea wind.  Flavor of very rich caramel, raisin and dark fruit, brown sugar, and heavy molasses.  Rich and smooth with a slightly dry finish and a hint of alcohol.  Pretty good.  (512, 556)

This was a cool looking bottle with the plastic stopper.  Im saving it. The pour is a reddish-mahogany brown with a decent three-quarters inch foamy, frothy head.  There is significant carbonation.  The aroma is malted to the max with a sweet molasses and toffee scent to it as well.  It really tingles my tongue with its very sweet taste and sharp bite at the end.

I thought, because of the "doppel" in the name, that Id be drinking a doppelbock, but as soon as I tasted it I knew it was not bottom fermented.

Really tastes like a top fermented version of a doppelbock, though.  Aroma is sweet, caramelly, malty and a hint of tannin.

Taste is similar but with a more musky, leathery and smoky redwood taste.  

Not a style I particularly favor, but if you like high-gravity, strongly malted beers, this is a well balanced, interesting brew.  Not cloyingly sweet, but definitely a malt-forward beer.

Bottle picked up at Chevy Chase in DC. Served in a pilsner glass.

Pours yields a deep molasses-colored brew with a good off-white head with good retention. Lacing sticks to the sides of the glass in a spotty fashion. The nose is incredibly rich with dark fruits, molasses, brown sugar, and some caramel. Its nearly a cross between a doppelbock and an eisbock. Really insanely enjoyable. The flavor doesnt back down, presenting a really nice fruity presence along with a touch of booze in the background. Mouthfeel is quite nice, but fails a bit in the finish. Good medium body presents itself well, but theres a bit too much bitterness in the finish, wiping away the beautiful flavor. Really quite drinkable. A solid hit on the best of Germany list.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-05-2011
This has a strong, sweet aroma. Nice maroon color, light lacing with particulates floating around. Soft on the palate. Great flavor with a slight bitter aftertaste.
U can really taste the Carmel. Especially in the after taste. Good beer for the price

UPDATED: APR 13, 2011 Draft. Sampled at Kickbacks. Served in a snifter glass and pours a dark, murky reddish mahagony brown color with a rich tan head. Some lace. Ive NEVER smelled an Altbier like this! Rich aroma of dark fruit raisin and plum with some caramel notes as well. Medium mouthfeel. Caramel notes off the bat along with the mentioned dark fruit notes. Some roasted flavors creep into the flavor as well. Fairly complex. Booze shows slightly and ends with a lingering bitterness.

Dark caramel colored pour with a small head. Aroma is much like an English style barleywine, with dark fruit, oxidation, and sweet molasses. The oxidation is almost to the right level, but I think its a bit past its peak, as theres some cardboard on the nose as well. Flavor is much the same, with lots of sweet malt. Interesting and decently tasty, but not great.
Brownish gravy color and very tasty. A full hopper that was a great change. I agree with these other guys it would go well with a mushroom topped steak.

My 10th altbier! 4/2/11. Flip top bottle courtesy emacgee! Cloudy dark brown pour with just about no head. Bold aroma of dark fruits, spices, molasses, and mint. Sweet barleywine flavor of dark fruits, molasses, oxidation, leather, and more. A bit odd, a little different, but not bad.
500ml bottle, courtesy of drowland, musty aroma, like A1 steak sauce. Rich, would go great with a nice steak.

The beer pours a medium to dark brown with a very light tan head that rises half an inch is gone within in seconds. The lacing is very light and watery to boot. The beer itself is surprinsgly clear, especially in the light.

The aroma very strong dominated by a toffee note with light hops.

The taste is surprinsingly bitter with a lingering bitter after taste. You dont get much of the sweet malts you get from the aroma so it really confuses the senses and doesnt make for an enjoyable experience

Mouthfeel is heavy and it sticks to your mouth for minutes. Not very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2011 Takes sticky to its literal conclusion.  Extremely, extremely sweet and sticky, like melted caramel.  Some dark fruits, a pretty complex flavor all-around.  But it kind of resembles a glazing gone wrong; burnt sugars like when I screw up a marinade for the oven.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a dark, reddish brown color with a very thin top for a head.  The head dissipates very quickly to a thin ring around the edge of the glass.  The nose is very malty and the association with a barley wine isnt off.  Malty with dark fruit notes and an obvious sweetness.  The flavor is strikingly smooth but rich with notes of dark dried fruit, dark caramel, dark bread, and raisin.  Very tasty.  Rich in body with low carbonation leading to a medium, warm finish.  This excellent brew is definitely worth trying.

Egészen sötétbarna színű sör, kis bíbor beütéssel. Habja világos drapp színű, vékony, krémes és elég gyorsan eltűnik, de nem minden nyom nélkül, hiszen egy vékony csipkét hagy maga után. Illata olyan, mint egy jó fajta árpabornak, aszalt gyümölcsös, édeskés, malátás, karamellás, karácsonyi süteményes. Az íz eleje is ilyen, gyümölcs likőrbe mártott, mazsolás, karamellás, melaszos és szárított gyümölcsös sütemény. Aztán jön rengeteg gyógynövény és gyantás komló, a maga szinte sokkoló és mégis kellemes kesernyésségével, egy kis bükkfafüstös és pirított kenyeres mellék ízzel, ami nagyon jól áll neki. Sűrű, olajos ital, ami egészen apró buborékokkal van tele és az alkohol szépen a háttérben marad. Utóíze medvecukros, keserédes a legvégén gyümölcsös és rendkívül száraz és nagyon kitartó. Fantasztikusan összetett és ravasz ital. Aki az illat alapján, először egy desszertsörre számít, az biztos, hogy összetekeredett nyelvel és görcsbe ránduló garattal fog a földre hanyatlani! Zseniális!
Clearly barley-wine oriented, very warm malt notes, intense earthy bitterness. Despite being at the limit of the style, this is a very good beer. Thanks Uerige!
Uerige is not my favorite beer. I think it is very special and it taste a little bit bitter. The aroma is ok. But last time i have a big headache at the next morning. Well, i have a lot of them ;)

Bottle@Gråsälstasting. Poured dark red/brown with a light brown head. Aroma is dark fruits and malt. Flavor is dark fruits, heavy malt and sweet. Wonderful sweet, slightly roasted finish. Very enjoyable.

Murky brown red pour. Small head, great lacing retention.  Aroma took me back immediately because it smelled like an unbelievable barley wine.Taste was dark fruits, abundant roasted malts, caramel, candy sugar, slightly hoppy. Finishes with a grapey sweet booziness similiar to a Belgian Strong. Flavor lingers on the tongue. Simply delicious, and beers like this might make me think that Germans can make decent brews.

Bottle with flip-top. Poured dark brown with a reddish twist in colour and a tan head. Aroma is a bit sweet and malty. Dark fruits, malt, bread and perhaps even some chocolate flavours - blended all together very well. A bit burnt flavour too. Nice  and smooth aftertaste.

Pours a really nice caramel color with minimal head. The alcohol hits right away followed by malt, malt malt. Really nice. Lightly oxidized. Tastes almost like a slightly burnt piece of rye toast with molasses on it, but in a good way if you know what I mean. Underlying hop flavor. Dont drink if your looking for a hoppy barley wine. This is more subtle and even than something like gnarleywine. Would love to drink more of these!

poured from the standard swing top 11.2 oz bottle.

Appearance: hazy, cloudy caramel color. Nice foam lacing on the glass with a thin head that sticks around for just a few minutes.

Smell: the smell hit me like a ton of bricks when i popped the bottle. heavy alcohol smell followed by roasted malt and caramel. Some molasses around the edges. the alcohol smell dissipates fast, this is smelling awsome

Taste: First sip was slightly boozy but that went away quickly as it did on the smell. Rich, Heavy malt flavors like a doppelbock, caramel tones and some roasted malt flavors intermingled. A lot of bittersweet taste to this like it has a bitterness that wants to get out but a sweet bready flavor buries it before it has a chance to overtake. 

Mouthfeel: rich and colorful is how i want to say it. it dances on the toungue with its full flavors but a nice balance and very smooth.

Drinkability: slightly boozy. thick. I think it comes in the 11.2 oz (330ml) bottle because that is probably just the right amount of this.
I think i could drink this late in the night in front of a fire with some almost over the top camambert cheese with smoked meats and dry rye bread or rye crackers.

330 mL swingtop bottle.  Pours hazy deep caramel with a light tan head.  Syrupy aroma with heavy molasses, bread, raisin, and dusty oxidative notes.  Flavor has the molasses, crusty bread, and raisin, some iced tea, but theres a lot of cardboardy oxidation going on.  I can taste that this would probably be really great without the oxidation, but its just okay in this condition.
A double altbier. IT i pretty alcoholic and caramally. It isnt as good at the regular. Get it fresh as old bottles tend to taste pretty crappy.

Visual: Pours off white head. Very murky reddish dark brown.

Nose: Very fragrant malts, honey, honeysuckle, dates, figs, and rose.

Palate: Slightly smokey, sticky roasted and toasted malts, wholegrain bread, pearbutter, Dates, figs, rose, honey, honeysuckle, minerals, spicey noble hops.

Conclusion: This is a special beer for special occasions. This beer is fairly sweet, however you cannot put it down. I am very pleased to find such a strong honey and rose chracter in this beer. And as far as I understand, no such things were added to this beer. This is a world class beer that should be in everyones house for special gatherings. So fragrant and alive with character...
. Cloudy reddish pour wtih a very small head. Aroma is really malty with some caramel, toffee, and sweet fruit. Flavor is again very malty. Caramel and toffee are everywhere/. Smooth and enjoyable!

This poured a darker red color with a beige head. Aroma was very very sweet, almost all caramel and toffee and light dark fruits, and some other strange off notes too that I cant quite put my finger on. Flavor was disgustingly sweet and caramel like, very cloying and just altogether bad IMHO.

Pours a thick murky like brown hue, no head to speak of. Slight hints of sweetness hits the nose followed by a strong malt smell.  Taste is outstanding a toasted malty flavor with a tangy citrus finish. The carbonation in the finish is great. This beer is going in to my steady rotation. Its delicious!!!

Sampled at SBWF-10
Deep amber.
Sweet, roasted, smoked and oliy.
Soft and smooth with nice warming alcohol.

This beer pours deep dark amber with a dark ruby hue and decent off white head. The aroma very similar to a tame barleywine - strong sweet malt notes, it pretty much smells like brandy. The flavor is strong and boozy, with notes of caramel, bitter notes from the hops, and then a light sticky warmness from the malts and the higher than normal ABV for the style.

Tasted from a 11.2 oz bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Pours a very dark red/brown body.  Great sweet medium to dark amber malty aroma thats fairly strong.  Strong dark amber malty body with a bit of a kick.  Good sweet malts.  Tasty brew.
A carbonated mouth-full of caramel and wheat bread.  The sugar stays in the background, allowing the earthy flavors to come through in a long finish.  A keeper.

This beer has the aroma of cane syrup and a flavor that is similar. With a thick and sticky body, the beer has a mix of flavors including sugar cane, caramel, chocolates, and a well-done beef roast. Very tasty.

Big caramel aroma, slightly oxidized, dried plums, raisins, very rich, somewhat vineous. Dark brown with orange and bubbly lace. Rich, sweet, strong. Feels like more than 8.5%, with a very bitter finish. Fruitcake, raisins, caramel. Huge flavors, completely unrestrained. Bitter after burn lasts for ages. Interesting and exciting, though I dare say less perfect than its little brothers. Slightly overwhelming and unbalanced, yet still good.

Bottle from Masons Pub in Huntsville, AL. Pours a dark, opaque brown with a large tan head. The aroma is heavy roasted malts, toffee, pine tar, and light smokiness. The flavor is very sweet, with significant bitterness in the finish. The body is very heavy, and the mouth-feel is thick and sticky with a malt-like powdery texture. Overall, a superb beer. Very strong, almost overpowering, but still subtle.

Outstanding.  Hazy deep brown in the glass.  Head was very light and dissipated rather quickly.  Thick on the palate with an almost oily quality.   Moderately bitter from the hops (but a good bitter) and slightly sour.  Apricot, honey, smoke on the nose...no question about it being a barley-wine.  Bonus points for using the cool and expensive bottle.   This looks like a serious beer, and tastes like one too.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2011 Bottled on 6. October 2010, into baby Chimay (180ml) chalice. Pours murky, deep coppery to bronze body topped by light tan, frothy head that slowly recedes. The deep nature of color probably results from usage of additional chocolate and/or black malts. The nose is loaded with rich malty sweetness with toasty notes, tons of fruity esters of plum, prune, raisins and figs, slightly spicy from usage of noble hops with citrus rind notes, brandy like alcohol. The assertive hoppy bitterness is counterbalanced by rich malty flavor with toasty notes; dark fruits are lesser than in the aroma; peppery noble hops flavor with strong citrus rind notes and intense bitter finish that lingers for ages. The brewer claims caramel malts containing complex sugars have been used in this one and thats reflected in rich malt flavor and fullness of the body with less attenuation. Creamy and velvety smooth, verging on being syrupy with soft carbonation. The lagering of this basically an ale has nicely smoothened the beer without taking away any of its complexity.

In short: a complex, fruity, bitter yet malty lagered ale.
SBWF 2010. Dark amber color, small head. Malty aroma, fruity, figs and some smoky notes. Malty flavor, spicy, some chocolate, figs, dadels, sweet fruits. Lovely beer with a smooth malty finish.

Bottle (bottled in January 2009). Nice Michael Jackson commercial description. I know that I have had this at least 4 or 5 times before; cannot believe that I havent rated it. Pours with a murky dark brown body and a small tan head that fades. Aroma is extremely vinous with notes of plums, caramel, dark fruits, tar, port, salt water toffee, wet hay, and pluots. Flavors of alcohol, caramel, plums, dark fruit, large bitterness, very vivid raisins on the mid palate, light salt, caramel, brandy and burnt flan. A great beer to pair with traditional strudel. Creamy carbonation. Long duration. A very good beer and one that has aged pretty well, and could go for another 6 months or so. Ironic to drink this two days after the traditional fall Sticke day.

bottle, donated by pivnizub, rated in December 2009. Deep amber colour, large white head. Bitter-sweet, smooth palate, typical Altbier flavours going on. A delciious and very smooth beer. I could drink this any time.

0.33 l bottle. Slightly hazy dark reddish brown. Very berryish and resiny aroma with toffee and sweaty hops. Toffeish, berryish, biscuity, resiny and bitter flavor.  There is some disturbing soapiness. Still, nice German barley wine, firm taste.

My third tasting in the Uerige "trilogy". A dark purplish brown brew with sweet roasty malts and raisin & plum notes. Nice fruity hop balance. Very smooth, slightly warming medium to heavy body. With a long lasting roasty finish. Very excellent stuff!

Dark mahogany aroma with little yellow head. Rich aroma with sweet raisins dominating, nice and smooth grassy hops also here. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is also raisinny with dark plummy tone, strong hops in aftertaste, still sweet sugary note lasts with some licorice. Excellent beer.
Same bottle as pictured. Older bottle. Pours little head. Little bit of fruityness to a overall dark beer. "What does this taste like?" is the first thought I had.
Surpisingly very fruity, tasted as if there were berrys. Very nice beer, the first taste was like "what is this" and then as you drink more the beer becomes quite nice

Bottle pours caramel brown with almost no head at all. Aroma is apples, caramel and bread. Taste very upfront sweet followed by a sour bitterness, fruits and caramel, yeast and bread on the finish. Interesting my first Altbier.
Pours a thin brown and smells very sweet. Sweet flavor followed by an alcohol kick and a very bitter aftertaste that is unattributable to any strain of hops.

The beer a hazy brown color with a tan head. The aroma is a ton of caramel malt with some chocolate and earthy hops mixed in. The flavor is similar. I get caramel malt, earth and dirty hops, chocolate malt and smoke. The alcohol is fairly noticeable and the bitterness from the hops is low. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Glad I got to try this one.

Bottle: After sampling another Uerige brew, I was afraid for my life, but it opened safely and without incident this time. Pours a dark brown, with a light off white head. Smells of malt, bread, fruit, and a little earthy. Flavors are quite similar , but what i noticed is how well they all tend to blend together, finishing quite smoothly. Fantastic

Interesting shaped bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a medium-sized off-white head.  Huge aroma of dark fruit, caramel, brown sugar, and hops.  Taste has a good amount of complexity.  Caramel malts, hops, and some fruity notes dominate.  Slightly nutty and the alcohol is slightly noticeable at first.  Finish is very nice: slightly sweet with chocolate malts.  A well-balanced and delicious beer.
dark, cloudy and thick.  sweet, caramel malts.  very filling, yet smooth.  a very good beer.
This was really good. Quite rich. The missus said, "This is what beer should taste like" Serving: Bottle

pour is brown and thick. light tan head.  cloudy and yeast layer in bottle.  Nose is massive--brown sugar, berry jelly, sweet malt and floral hops.  Another beer that can be sniffed around on for a long time.  Taste is sweet and rich of chocolate mocha, burnt caramel, and roasted fruits.  Mouthfeel is a perfect balance.  Leaves you warm and bitter.  Aroma was better than taste but still a wonderful beer.

33cl bottle. Pours a dark ruby-brown color with a creamy off-white head. Lonf lasting foam. Spicy aroma with malty caramel, burnt sugar, alcohol hints and fruity esters. Taste is mostly sweet and fruity, with spicies and some caramel notes. Alcohol is very well hidden. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, a wonderful beer, remembering me of some belgian strongs.

Dark brown/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, rich caramel, toffee, some dark fruit, & spice; Flavor roasted sweet malt, molasses, caramel, spicy hops, nuts, and dark fruit; Finish is slightly bitter; The alcohol is well hidden; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, very good - I enjoyed it.

Draft at Churchkey in DC. Sweet, maple-caramel-syrupy nose over a dark brown beer. Quite sweet with a somewhat harsh, tea-like, hop-pellet bitterness attempting to balance and not quite pulling it off. Malt and hops both stand out but theres no harmony here. Disappointing from the makers of my very favorite Alt. Ill take the regular stuff -- and lots of it, fresh -- any day over this somewhat messy experience.
5th March 2010. Pre ZBF after tasting. Cloudy brown beer. Aged tasting caramel malt. A little fruit and some spicy malt and some toffee. Alcohol heat as well!

On tap at Papago.  Pours a dark shade of amber wih a creamy beige head.  Smells and tastes predominantly of red apple skins and buttered rice.  Nice combination of caramel, malt, and fruit.  Go, Altbier!

Raisins, cocoa and candied fruit in the nose.  Very dark brown, reddish highlights, tan head.  Smooth palate, tons of dark fruit in the palate, mainly prunes.  A bit sweet, a bit sticky.  Almost too much of the sweet, but still, enjoyable.

A Mes rate. Bottle at our hotel in Bruge after Pre ZBF.Murky amber with a thin white head. Cardboard and syrup aroma. A little more interesting in the flavour for certain but not something I could really enjoy. Good chewy fruit and some interesting bitterness in the finish, thats about it. A bit meh overall.

Deep muddy brown coloured body with ruby and toffee highlights and a very thin tan head. Aroma of raisins, caramel, malt, toffee, cherries, figs and pungent alcohol. Full-bodied; Deep pungent malt, alcohol and pit fruit flavours that show a lot of bitter sugars, strong fruits (deep raisins and prunes) and a overwhelming toffee and caramel flavour. Aftertaste shows a strong alcohol bite, pungent malt and a never-ending bitter fruit note - fairly nice! Overall, an old-school barleywine made before the style existed - but showing to German characteristics. Nice to sample - strong as hell, more body and complex flavours than a doppelbock and worth trying if you can find it! I sampled this 33 cL swing-top bottle purchased from German Gourmet in Falls Church, Virginia on 22-May-2010 for US$4.75 sampled at home in Washington on 15-June-2010.

Bottle - this bottle is off the hook! Definitely saving it for some homebrew. Pours a nice dark brown, clear at first but definitely not by the end of the pour. Nice tan head, too. Nose is burnt caramel with maybe a little smoke. Flavor is big, rich malt and very German yeast tones - quite like a doppelbock, really, but then theres that little roasted note alongside. Im not sure that its really a "German barleywine," as its pretty much just a doppelbock with a little extra. Still, though, an interesting and tasty brew.

Sampled on draft at Zenos in State College PA this beer poured a murky dark brown color with a very small brown head that lingered and produced some lacing. The aroma was sweetish, nutty and lightly fruity. The flavor was bitter with sour nut, caramel, cherries, elderberries, tobacco and a touch of wood. The finish was long and malty with lingering fruity and tobacco. Very full bodied and nicely complex. The alcohol was well hidden. Nice.
Tap @ Boston/NY 2009. Black color, short head. Aroma of malt, some chocolat, hint of fruit. Sweetish fruity chocolate. Lovely stuff.

Tap at Ginger Man NYC. Pours a slightly cloudy, dark, amber-brown with a moderate, off-white head. Deeply malty aroma, plenty of dark fruits such as raisin, date and fig, along with caramel and light chocolate. Flavor is nice and sweet, more fruit and an everpresent caramel character. Some hints of booze. A strong, medium body with average carbonation and lightly warming. As with other Uerige beers, this one finishes with a distinct dryness. Overall quite a nice beer.

The bottle looks really, really good, nice format. Beer in the glass dark, almost black, small head. Malty aroma, a bit alcoholic. Starts strong-malty, a bit smoky, some notes of liqorice. Finish a little bit smoky, wonderful balanced and very drinkable. Warming aftertaste. Great beer!

Bottle @ UDRM. The aroma has grass, caramel, raisin and is a bit sweetish sticky as far as aroma can have such a property. Bit hazy, brown-red coloured beer with an off-white, thin head. The taste has laurel, caramel, grass, a bit yeast, some prunes. The taste is amazing, it is a very well made beer.
Sampled at "Guess Whos Back..." tasting. Aroma is nice- a spicy burnt toast nose, flavor though is dirt and sugar. Eww.

33cL flip-top bottle.  A deep garnet color with a one-finger tan head that leaves a decent amount of lacing.  Aromas of grape juice, raisins, molasses, and berries.  Flavor is mostly sweet; candi sugar, caramel, brown sugar.  A slightly bitter, yeasty finish with some grassy hops present.  Creamy and warming mouthfeel.  Very nice.
Guess whos back tasting. Smells like a doppelbock. Pours black with a light off white head. Tastes like a hoppy doppelbock. Malty and sweet.
Sampled at the Guess Whos Back tasting.  Clear dark brown pour.  Sweet nose with molasses.  Flavor of toast, lightly anise, raisin. plum.  I thought it was a  dopplebock.
Pours a wet, lacing almost beige head with a very dark, copper body.  Aromas of dark bread, brown sugar, a little dogfood.  Flavors of dark bread, brown sugar, yeast, some dogfood.  Finish is dry.

11.2 fl oz bottle. I really agree with the description of this being a German-style barleywine, and very tasty barleywine at that. It really is like a big brother (or bigger version) of the regular Sticke with similar notes, just more pronounced. Nutty German cookie, fresh water grass, light cherries and berries, some date, light molasses, mixed citrus fruits, and some mixed malted cereal grains. Much more hit-you-in-the-face than the regular. On the pour, a nice layer of light creamy head, that mostly dissipates, a medium thick body, and dark copper in color. A full, creamy mouth feel here with a nice kick without any hint of alcohol. Also, fairly warming. Slightly hoppier than the regular, and with more of a fruit aspect to it. Dark mixed, bittersweet fruits, buttery/nutty malted cereal grains, light molasses, cookies, mixed citrus fruits. The finish is nicely bitter with a fruity herbal combination. When it comes down to it, this is a unique, yet high quality sipping beer. Overall, I would have to rate this one slightly ahead of the Sticke. Very good stuff.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Brown colored brew. Lots of malts in the aroma, raisins. Flavor is malty, hops, roast, full flavored. Very nice.

Pours a very hazy, deep brown with big yeast chunks in suspension and a 1-inch off-white head. Aroma has a great hefty toasted malt note, light caramel, mild chocolate and some low toffee and yeasty notes. Flavor has a very strong caramel presence, lots of mild toasted notes, modest amount of chocolate, light toffee and lots of malt sugary density with no hops aroma. Body is pretty hefty with low carbonation and a nice creamy sugary flavor. Overall a very solid brew and one that was surprisingly good. Very hefty with a strong flavor profile, making this a brew to sip on colder evenings.
Dark, chocolatey, very very malty, raisiney, cloudy appearance.  Great aroma.  The only drawback I feel this beer has is that it is kind of reminiscent of cough medicine.

Dark brown colour, light brown head, good lace. Same as the aroma loads of malts but also liquid hops are added. Very sticky mouth feel. Great beer!

Swing top bottle @ URBM, Oirschot. Best  beer of this great session. Very malty aroma and flavor with raisin, oak, laurel, armagnac. Alcoholic, but with loads of herbal hops. Great balance, astonishing beer!

Bottle @ RB meeting by Joes. A clear dark red colored , with a beige head. The aroma of sweet malts a little alcohol and fruits. The taste has a lot of malts notes, sweet a little wood with laurel and hops. A little sticky. The aftertaste is moving from sweet to bitter.

Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing jbrus! Pours a hazy deep dark coppery color with a red glow and some floaties, with a creamy off-white head. Very intense aroma of loads of sugary malt, but nicely balanced by loads of floral hops. The flavor is even richer, an avalanche of sugary sweetness paired with hoppy bitterness in an extremely nice balanced way. More towards the bitter hoppy side in the finish. Very full bodied amazing brew.
Bottle. Pours brown, with a tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, and fruit. Flavor is caramel, hops, malt, and fruit. Medium to heavy body.
Bottle. Murky brown with no head. Caramel and toffee and nutty flavour. Some oxidation that leads to a sourish finish. Not good.

bottle - hazy brownish beer with a thin beige head. Aroma has a nose of fresh and fruity hops. Flavour comes with a heavy maltiness and ends with a well balanced bitterness. Full body and soft carbonation.

[bottle from bierkompass.de]
Rich cereal grain / pumpernickel aroma with raisin, tobacco, dried fruit accents and no detectable hops. Hazy dark brown under a white patch and ring. Flavour is of potent grain, cereal, pumpernickel, but contains a hops note that was not present in the aroma. Assertive bitterness is in blance with the sweet specialty malt. Bread crust and faint liquorice notes come out late. Medium body, moderate to medium carbonation, slightly bitter finish.

Bottle at post pre ZBF 2010.  I had great hopes for this.  Some cardboard, oxidation on aroma.  Better in mouth.  Not as good as either the regular which I had in Dusseldorf in the brewpub or the Sticke I had at Battersea BF.  VEry syrupy and nutty in mouth.  Not great.

0,33 l bottle, bought at the PreZBF Festivals beershop.
Poured deeeeeep brown-ruby, near black body with a fantastic, foamy tan-beige head. The beers aroma comes like a steamer. Thick, characteristic one... Liqueric, roasted perfumes with a ton of dried fruits, dark chocolate and caramel. Complex aroma like the flavor....Oily texture, thick body with a taste bomb of roasted grains, fruits like plum and raisins, liqueric molasses and caramel. Very complex, beautiful brew.

dear god, this is impressive. pours mud brown/brick red, cloudy with heavy carbonation. aroma is malty, astringent and spices. flavor is like a cross between a dark hefe and a belgian ale. caramel, butter, brown sugar, molasses, overripe fruit like bananas and pears, and mild herbage. a soft glowing aftertaste with some low alcohol burn. and a cool bottle to boot!

Draft at Bavarian Lodge. Pours a somewhat opaque brown red, thin head. On nose, I get fusel notes, roasty notes, Noble hop notes. On taste, it is too cold at first resulting in sticky notes with heavy alcohol character. Some of the roast peaks through, though it is a heavy beer and difficult to drink. As it warmed, it melded much better with rising temperatures as some raisin came through and a pleasant bitterness to balance the body. Okay, though probably not great.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL. and served in a short, Altbier glass. The color was a clear, dark brown with ruby highlights. The head was modest, creamy tan foam that reduced to a film but left some nice sheeting lace on the interior of the glass. The aroma was toasty, rich malt, caramel, and dark, dried fruit as raisins and plums. The flavor added to these a brown sugar sweetness, and a necessary, strong hop bitterness to balance with all of the other assertive notes. The alcohol presence was smooth, the body was full, and the hop bitterness continued undeterred into the finish. Very impressive!

Bottle. 
Pours brown with some carbonation bubbles but no head.
Lots and lots of malt, cola popcicles, soy and hops. 

Defenitely one of the best and most interestign german beers Ive had.

Bottle. Oh my god! What a beer! Sweet aroma of caramel ice cream, chocolate, some hops, and lots of malt. The taste is a "well balanced malt overdose". Notes of burned caramel, malty tartness, sweet bread, cocoa. Incredible mouthfeel and balance. Youre able to notice all nuances of the beer. Its a heavy tasting beer with a kind of light body wich makes it easy to drink.

Cask at redlight redlight.  Pours a deep cloudy amber.  Great nose with a lot of caramel, wood, robust malts.  the flavor is slightly sweet with a great bitter finish and noticeable kick from the high alcohol.  Excellent sticky mouth-feel.  I really like it.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a dark ruby in color with a slightly tan head.  The aroma is fruity and sweet.  Flavor notes are strong on dried fruits - plums, caramel, slight vinous note.  Finish is strong, but not overpowering.  Strong on the prune, molasses, warm alcoholic kick.

Pours a light to medium brown haze with a very thin head.  Has an aroma of fruit and caramel.  Has a roasty, caramel taste, with some bitter.  Can definitely pick up the barley wine feel on the finish and aftertaste.  A watery mouthfeel.  Not in love with this beer.

11.2 fl oz swing top bottle purchased at Lukas Liquors in Kansas City, Missouri. Pour is a very hazed brown copper ruby with a well formed two inch light tan head.  Eventually falls with nice coating lace.  Aroma is gentle maltiness, nice grain and light sweetness. Behind the malt is an interesting spice, almost clove yeastiness. Taste is the malt, full and cereal grain sweet, followed closely by a licorice anise flavor that was surprising, but not unpleasant. As it warms, this yields to a softer almost soy taste, that also turns quite dry in the finish. The dry finish reveals a bit of the alcohol heat. Palate is medium bodied, with above average lively carbonation. As mentioned, alcohol is present in the finish and warms the chest. Unique beer, very original flavor profile.

it truly is like a cross between a barley wine and an altbier.   The aroma is fruity, earthy, doughy, boozy.   The flavor is very sweet, caramel, fruit, booze.  The finish has a sweet quality, but also a slight hop bitterness that saves it.  The mouthfeel is sticky, thick body.  Unique among altbiers, and excellent.

Bottle. Pour was deep hazy brown with a very lively aroma of fruit, medium spice, and sweet malt and toffee. Balance is the name of the game in this brew, and boy, was this a tasty beverage. Seemingly perfect balance in sweetness to the very yeasty fruitiness and very light hop background. No alcohol was detected but it was warming on the way down. Very fine brew. I will look for this one again.

Like a cross between an english barleywine (Nils Oscar comes to mind as I tried it recently) and a doppelbock (think Korbinian), very sweet, doughy, malt but with a ton of fruity tang and a mildly sticky feel. The flavor is mostly sweet doughy malt. It has a vinous and near-brandy quality. Its not as rich as a straight malt bomb. There is a much more delicate quality, particularly in a fruity yeast, ripe plums and bananas, and mineral to earthy hops. I guess there are probably sweet notes of caramel and chocolate lurking, but the sweetness comes through more in a barleywine flavor than most highly malty styles. The beer is a bit sticky sweet. Dont get me wrong. I certainly wouldnt recommend this as a session beer. In fact, it may be getting more difficult to drink as I go through the bottle. Its a lot of sweetness. That said, I would very much enjoy having a case of these to open whenever I was in the mood.

(bottle) pours a clear ruby-copper colour with a creamy beige head. aroma of strawberries and passion fruit pulp, lots of berries, heavy caramel and dark toasted malts. flavour is similarly fruity, with lots of raisins and a long grainy roasted-bitter herbal hoppy finish, alcohol is well-hidden. medium to heavy body with smooth carbonation. nice one!

Substituted a Tom Collins glass for my lack of an alt, close enough.  330 mL bottle pours a deep, resiny red-brown with minimal off white head.  Aroma of powdery cocoa, almost seems like Ovaltine; earthy, raspberries, plenty of roasted malts, nice unique smell.  Taste lives up the aroma: Powdered cocoa/earthiness holds throughout each drink, develops into raspberries, milk sugar.  Finishes creamy with chocolate roasted malt.  Silky mouthfeel with low carbonation.  Full bodied.  This was even better than the first time I had it, very good.

Bottled on 05.03 and served in an Ayinger Celebrator glass. Pours clear dark brown with a half inch capping of khaki foam. The smell is reminiscent of a good barleywine. Notes of molasses, earth, honey, mint, and brown sugar. The flavor is very earthy with a lot of herbal mint and brown sugar underneath. The mouthfeel is very full and smooth with low carbonation. The finish lasts for quite sometime and leaves a simultaneous warming and cooling effect. Unlike any other German beer that I have ever had. Quite excellent.

This vintage 2003 poured a really nice dark brown. The aroma is sweet malt and caramel which is exactly how the taste comes across to me. Sticky and thick is the best way to describe the palate. I would love to taste this beer a little younger just to see what aging does for it. Im guessing it ages beautifully since the 2003 was so smooth. Im thinking this beer is good candidate for you personal shelves!
