Tap. Dark brown with creamy chocolate-milk colored head. Flavor is malt, raisins.

2008 vintage. pours brown caramel color with large head.  aroma is full of caramel and sweet malts. drinks really smooth with caramel being the most prominent flavor. some candied fruits in there also but mostly just sweet caramel. fantastic offering. would love another.

~ Purchased this bottle from Big Z Beverage in Huntington, NY. This beer pours a dark brown with almost no head. The aroma consists of dark fruits, caramel, malt sweetness, and some spices. The taste is very similar to its smell. At 8.5% ABV, this went down surprisingly very smooth. 

All in all, this is a beer thats rich, bold, flavorful, and tastes great- what more could you ask for? ~

Deep mahogany maple syrup pour w/ two finger foamy/creamy head, aroma is buttered toast and some dried cherry and rum, syrupy alcohol mouthfeel, sweet fruit up front that quickly leads to some hop bitterness before fading to a lingering warm alcohol finish. Good representative of the style.
Tap. Sticky malt up front that backs off after a moment, some raisins, earthy, caramel. I can understand the comparisons to barley-wine.  An interesting brew.

Starts out tasting like a barley wine - very sweet with brown sugar caramel flavors and a ton of hops - when it warms it starts tasting buttery - couldnt finish this - way too sweet and heavy, and the butter was disgusting. Plus alcohol came through too much for 8.5%. The flavor at first did seem nice / well made, but it was ultimately blech anyway.

33cl bottle thanks to diomede.   Dark amber with a small beige head.   Thick, bready malt aroma.   Huge bready malt character with a surprising dryness and strong bitterness that balances the malt well.   Alcohol is present but not too hot.   Medium bodied with medium-light carbonation.   Pretty straight-forward stuff but nice.

BOTTLING DATE: 05-07

Excellent looking dark ruby color that almost appears to be black. Four finger tan head with abit of retention that fades down to a nice thin foam with excellent lacing.

Nice dark malty smell. Hints of dark fruits. A touch of hops.

Caramel maltiness, front and center. Toasted wheat mingles with dark cherries, figs and over-ripe grapes. Very slight hop spiciness on the back-end.

Feels quite nice in the mouth. Could be thicker and heavier (for me) but its definitely not too thin. Mmmm.

Even with the extra bit of alcohol content, this is very drinkable. A very tasty brew here. If you ever see it, try it. Its worth it.

Dark, beautiful, brown color. Perfect tan/cream colored head. Everything a German beer should look like. Very mild leather and nut aroma. Great nutty, raisiny, slightly spicy flavor. Very earthy and much more like a harvest ale/barleywine/etc than I expected. Great beer. Ends with a nice bitterness akin to less hoppy IPAs. Dont misunderstand me, you arent going to get big citrus and flower notes in the flavor, just a nice bitterness to round out all the heavy maltiness. My only complaint is that the palate is a bit sticky and feels like theres a film on the roof of my mouth. Overall though, an excellent beer and probably the best dopplebock Ive ever had.

courtesy of fiulijn; a huge thank you for this one! - clear brown colour with a poor head retention; very malty, nutty and earthy aroma with a solid hop presence and some alcohol notes too; sticky and full-bodied, a solid malt sweetness; very bitter and long malty earthy and hoppy finish - robust and complex, a great beer

Bottle. Dark brown color. Very impressive aroma. Clean and crisp balance of fruit, alcohol, malt and hops. Slightly citric, roasted malt, caramelly, like honey-roasted almonds. Red fruits in rum, strawberries, raspberries. A faint hint of noble hops in the last whift. Very reminicent of some great american Barley Wine. Flavor is big with raisiny sweetness, caramel, nuts, dried fruits and preserves. Really syrupy sweet, but just barely rescued by a roasted malt finish and a dry bitter bite.

Swingtop bottle pours a hazy, dark chestnut body with a small beige head that leaves island chain lacing. Malty aroma has toffee and chocolate with some spicy hops. Taste is malt driven, as well. Toffee, caramel, dark chocolate, dark frutis, nuttiness, and a hint of roast. Spicy hops add balancing bitterness. Very flavorful. Topnotch for style.

Bottle 330ml. w. swing top.Clear medium amber color with a virtually none head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, oxidide malt, light alcoholic, dryed dark fruits. Flavor is light heavy sweet with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20090913]

Bottle at Papsø.
Hazy orange red coloured with a small off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel and dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel and dried fruits.
Sweet finish.
Hazy with a tiny beige head. Sweet and oxidized aroma with caramel and malty notes. Flavour was sweet and had overripe fruits, malt, caramel and hoppy notes. Finished sweet with warming alcohol.

Bottled. An unclear brown beer with a thin tan head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and some fruit. The flavor is very sweet with notes of caramel, malt, and a bit of alcohol, leading to an alcohol dry finish. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

cloudy brown, very small head.
aroma is old beer, spices, alc, caramel and toffee.
flavor is dark fruits, syrupy,

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Small almost non existing head. Sweetness, bread, ripe fruits and light spice in the aroma. Flavour of ripe fruits, sweetness, spice and caramel. Medium bodied. Ends on a sweet and light spiced note.
33 cL bottle. Pours murky dark brown with no head. Aroma is wineous and cheesy. Mild caramelish and wineous flavoured. Sweet and sticky flavoured. Lingering malty flavoured finish.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Pours a slightly hazy deep amber with a tiny off-white head. Oxidized aroma, malt, pumpernickel and caramel. Low in carbonation. Medium body, sweet carabel and oxidized malts. No real bitterness. 130909
Pours brownish red with a tan head.  Smells of sweet malt, some spicy hints, peppery.  Tastes of layered malt, some nutty hints, some rosey hints, caramel, touches of spice.

sewage brown pour, devoid of carb.  ultra nutty, malty aroma that mimics the color.  flavor is chewy as is possible with the high ABV blending perfectly into sweet roasted nuts and sheets of melting bitter caramel.  tangy grapes muddle with dark toffee.  even with a bad seal (due to swiveltop no doubt) this is a potent and still enjoyable big beer.

Bottle from Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City.  Pours dark brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma is caramel malt, honey, dark fruits, and spice.  Flavor is more of the same with figs, spiced rum, and mild roast.  Body only medium, but palate is still fairly syrupy.  It seems almost unfair to other beers in the style to classify this as an altbier since its so strong and intense.  This should be called an "imperial altbier" or something.  Its really more like a doppelbock.  Had this next to regular Uerige Sticke and it delivers a massive combination pimp smack/donkey punch upside the head of that more modest altbier.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2017 Pictured bottle dated 11/16; from Louisville Beer Store; had half the bottle to myself. Aroma: Moderate raisin liqueur with lighter toast and molasses; German hops come off as nearly medicinal/herbal in this setting. Appearance: Sedimented dark cola brown with a bubbly tan head that settles into a thin ring. Flavor: Rich malts mentioned previously up front; more sweet than toasty; has a surprisingly strong dose of bitter, medicinal hops towards the finish, which is mostly dry. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: Still a idiosyncratic beer, especially in todays IPA-ized craft beer market. Not an everyday drinker, but a wonderful occasional treat.

Aroma of alcoholic caramel and a slight amount of fig and dark fruit. Flavor: highly caramelized beer with a toasty character and a hint of fig. Palate is slightly syrupy initially, then tends toward moderate thickness. Finish is of fermented fruit. A good beer and reasonably well balanced.

Source:05/03 bottle consumed 08/09. 
Glass:Wine. 
Appearance:Dark brown pour with red highlights and a thin off white head.  
Aroma:Dark fruits, heavy caramel and toffee.  A hint of earth as well. 
Flavor:Heavy, chewy caramel with dark fruit and an earthy bitter finish. 
Palate:Full body with mild carbonation.
Overall:Got my vote.  Excellent beer.  Plan on buying more.

On tap at International Beer Garten (Lutz, FL).  Pours a dark brown color with a minimal off-white head.  Sweet, dried fruit aroma with hints of caramel malt.  Flavor had a lot of molasses characteristics to it.  Nice bitter aftertaste.

04/06 bottle, consumed 09. Pours a deep brown, not much head. Aroma is rich and sweet, earthy but a little flat - probably due to age. Flavors are similar but pick up something more - there is lingering character here that I wish I could have tasted fresh.
Dark brown pour, with nice brown head.  Dark fruit, molasses, brown sugar, figs, caramel malt, and a hint of burnt toast.  Very good beer.  Complex, nice mouthfeel, and just plain old tasty.

Dark brown pour with 1 finger beige head. Aroma is roast with some dark sugar. Caramel, molasses, brown sugar and fig. Flavor is loaded with dark fruits and dark sugars. Palate is medium with a clean sugary finish.

Tap at PIB. Pours out deep mahogany with a dark brown head. Aroma is big on the malt, caramel, cocoa and a little bit of pepper. Flavor is complex with caramel, cocoa, light pepper, toffee, figs. Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy. Very tasty.
Dark mahogany red with a lasting cola like head.  Aroma is big, caramel, toasted malt, cocoa.  Taste is big malt again, sweet, caramel, toffee, dark fruits, light thinning alcohol finish.  Solid.

Original review date 10/20/2008...

Swingtop POPS from one of the funkiest bottles going. 11.2 oz. into a Reidel Extreme Riesling glass.

2 fingers of rye bread head topping a huge root beer body with a little carbonation and a solid seam. Quite impressive.

A little metal off the top but this goes away quickly. Sweet doppelbock/sarsparilla scent. Slight pepper notes accompany this complex concoction. Not your babydaddys alt.

Thick, syrupy ups...malt is huge, malty, thick and formidable. Backbone has depth with a peanutty/caramel feel to it.

Hearty malt profile is extremely soothing - virtually no alcohol burn and finish is strong and solid.

Definitely a sipper. Easily drinkable but works best if savoring in small doses. Well-done.

Murky muddy chestnut brown.  Roasted malt, baking chocolate aroma.  Some fig and strawberry.  Maltball, caramel, and more bitter chocolate together in harmony and a bit of intensity.  Theres no punch in the mouth, but a quick warming in my chest.
sample at Ale Atlanta 6/4... pours a deep golden color.  very spicy and earthy aromas... medium body with lots of caramel and sweet malts.  very smooth finish with some dark fruits.  intriguing.

Dark opaque chocolate brown with no head (maybe to cold.) Nice lacing.    Smells like a malt bomb, very sweet, milk chocolate, overripe fruit, raisin.  My first impression is that its bad and must have been mishandled.  Very sharp on the tongue, bitter acrid bite covers everything else and lasts on the top og the tongue. A little bit of sweetness and raisin tries to peek through.  As it warms, it loses some of the edge off the bite, but still has an overwhelming leafy/woodsy bitterness.  As it warms some more, a dark chocolate and raisin flavor, along with a dark roasted malt compete with the bitter edge.  More alcohol becomes evident on the nose and the palate.  Aftertaste is still sharp.

Pours cloudy dark brown with tan head. Big, sweet, thick malty aroma with dark fruits, molasses, cherries. Very sweet. Big malty flavor with some cherry and dark fruits. Modedrately bitter finish. Thick, chewy mouthfeel with minimal carbonation. Very nice.

11.2 oz. bottle served in a Kolsch. Cola in color without the carbonation and a fluffy light tan head that fills 2/3 of the glass on the pour. Heavily malted, and raisiny (barleywine-style) on the nose. The palate... Wow! Big! Weighty body, thick, slick, and richly flavored. Dark fruits, molasses, and brown sugar. Long, oily, slightly bitter, malty finish. I will be having this again!

5l mini cask at redlight redlight.  Rich raisony aromas, dark fruits, dark cherries, plums, molasses.  Pours very dark amber with a thick off white head.  Rich dark fruits, dark cherry, dates, plums, raisons, with some chocolate and rich malty flavors.  So rich and malty, an awesome beer!
Poured dirty brown with a white head. Aroma of cherries and booze. Slight caramel and cherry flavor with a finish of straight booze.

12oz bottle courtesy of Kevin. I been dyin to try this one. I was stunned to see this was a altbier. I figured it was a doppelbock. It doesnt taste like most doppelbocks but its more like a doppel than an altbier imo. Pours a dark brown thats rather clear. Decent sized light chocolate head. Aroma was very malty with some raisins and caramel. Flavor was almost like an english barleywine. Super smooth with alot of sweet caramel, a decent bit of smoke and some spiced raisin bread. Finishes with just enough hops to keep things balanced. This is very very good.

On tap. Dark brown pour with the slightest hints at ruby on the edges.  A short, light-tan head that produced bits of lacing.  The aroma was mostly malt and spice that gives way to some floral and piney hops.  The flavor was neat, smokey malt that quickly transitions into bitter hops on the backside.  A Frankenstein-like creation of some dopplebock and an IPA.  The body is thin to medium, the finish crisp.  An interesting beer.

Courtesy MrBunn. Smells of brown sugar, molasses and dark fruit. Pours a dark brown, with a decent head. Almost like a barleywine. Good alcohol warmth on the way down. Rather sticky and sweet. End is a bit more than I would care for.

Sweet bottle with a stopper.  Pours a ruby brown with a small tan head.  Aromas are a nice enough mix of brown sugar, alcohol, topsoil, spice and raisins.  Flavor is thick and sweet up till the very end when it gets a blast of ABV and spice.  That said, this is a fairly smooth beer up till that moment... where it breaks down a bit and becomes just a bit rugged.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Poured cloudy dark brown. Earthy malt aroma. Taste was quite sweet. Some dark fruit and spice. Very creamy mouthfeel.
Dark, opaque brown with very nice lacing from the slight, yet thick, head. Malt aroma with a hint of spice. Taste of nuts and strong fruit flavor. Wonderfully drinkable. Thanks Nathan.

Bottle, picked up at Johns Grocery in Iowa City, IA. Opened with Tom at the "What this town needs is an IHOP" tasting. Rich brown pour, nice slowly devolving tan bubbles. Aroma of sweet raisiny yeast rolls, earthy cinnamon. Rich soft leathery malt, elegant and full. Woody hop finish. A generous, warming and elegant beer. If this is Germanys answer to the barleywine, it is one compelling bit of dialog.

Bottle. Black-brown, practically opaque with lots of lacing. Dark malt. Pumpernickel dough aromas include caraway spicing and raisins. Syrupy mouthfeel. Really malty, thick, sweet, bready and not burnt but caramelized. Has a nice spicy quality, I like it.

Gift from Nathan.  Pours a dark brown with a hint of cranberry hue.  Aroma is...fun?  Like Caribbean Punch.  I can smell the rum and pineapple juice distinctively.  Malt is present as well.  Flavor is full of malt and yeast.  Nuts and dark fruit flavors are in mid swallow.  It is slightly bitter on the finish.  Palate was a touch chalking, I thought.  I cant keep my nose out of this one though.

Bright clear brown-amber with a fine, medium-dense off-white head. Full, classically "German" aromas along with fruity fermentation esters, a touch of nutty malt, and some caramel. The flavor is a bit disarming at first in that it offers much fuller character from an aroma profile not normally associated with such dimension. The malt is well represented in the body alongside nutty flavor and intriguing yeast notes. A pleasant surprise.
Dark brown color with a medium tan head. Fruit and malts aromas. Silky smooth palate with the sweet malt and dark fruit flavors. It leaves a light tart finish

2006 bottle courtesy of retorp. Pours a cola brown color with thin off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of raisins, ripe dark fruit, plums, caramel, honey, some fresh fruit as well. Flavor is malty and sweet with caramel and toffee in addition to raisins, plums, some hints of molasses. Generally medium body with a malty and sweet finish.

Bottle.  Pours deep amber with no head.  Hop and malt balance in the nose.
Alcohol flavor up front, giving way to hop and malt and a somewhat spicy finish.  Great brew.

2006 bottle that poured murky brown with copper hues and off white head. The aroma is sweet and rich with ample amounts of chewy dark fruity esters, caramel and rich malts. The taste is much the same and seems silky smooth bringing in flavor notes on a dark velvet carpet. I get rich smooth dark fruitiness, some creamy sweet caramel and a background of faint yet sweet malts. Very nice. I would mistake this for an English style barleywine in a blind tasting. YUM. In fact I need to get more of this.

2006 bottle courtesy of retorp.
Pours clear brown with white head.
Aroma of caramel malts.
Taste has plenty of good malt and caramel. Strong fruity presence with sugary undertones.
A fine Altbier and with this abv, it is just very enjoyable.

On tap @ Redlight.  Dark, rich-looking caramel and mahogany color with a thin khaki head.  Rich, almost maple-like notes, rich caramel and molasses, figs.  Thick, sweet caramel taste, spice, heavy malt.  Thick, but nice.

poured like new motor oil, settling into a nice dark amber color. Head was eager and voluminous dissipating into large soapy bubbles. [4]

aroma was deep malt characters backed by some oak and brown sugar. Dark fruits lend a touch of spice in the nose as well. Strong and pleasing. [9]

flavor is very barley infused with a bright almost peppery heat initially. [75]

palate is a bit thin [2]

overall a joy on the eyes and nose and while it doesnt falter too badly on the tongue it felt like it could have been more.

330 mL awesome bottle. Pours  a clear dark amber/ reddish-brown with almost no carbonation and a beautiful beige cap that lasts for a while leaving good sheets of lacing. Aroma is incredibly sweet and malty with some raisins, prunes, figs with some roasted and earthy notes. Taste is well balanced with some spicy alcohol up front with dry, bittering hops complementing the heavy caramel malt. Finish is dry and tart with some excessive soapiness but Ill let it slide.

330 mL bottle.  Cloudy brown with little head.  Aroma is somewhat medicinal, with some licorice, chocolate and alcohol.  Lots of malt in the flavour.  Some chocolate and dark fruit.  Sweetness is balanced just enough by the hops.  Very full and creamy.  A little alcohol at the end.  Very good.

A: Hazy brown, little head.

S: Sweet, figs, malts, smoky

T: Raisins, too much as a matter of fact. Some bitterness, sweet. Almost too complex, each taste spins my buds a round. No balance.

M: oily coating, little carbonation. 

D: Tough to finish the whole bottle. I much prefer the Alt. Doesn’t do it for me at all.

7oz Draft at Uber, NYE. Tight, dense pour with cappuccino head. cool glassware too, perfect for this little beer. deep copper appearance with a heavy head, fresh nose. Flavor is hoppy and metallic, sweet and alt-malty. flat/smoky, whiff of licorice.

7 oz pour at Uber - New Year’s speical. Pours a transparent red amber - very pretty. Thick, dense head - wasn’t expecting that. Sweet aroma - lots of malts, and honey-glazed dark fruits. Flavor is right on line - very sticky sweet, but not offensively so. The flavor is still mostly malts - there’s a hop presence, but it’s very slight. Low carbonation. Surprisingly drinkable.

Bottle.  Reddish brown, with a medium beige head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is caramel, sweet, raisin, some chocolate, nuts.  Flavor is mildly bitter, with a nice chocolate  and oak finish.  Delicious malt assault.  Very good beer.

clear dark brown under a large creamy beige head.  big potent raisin, plum, cocoa, dog food, nutty, toffee aroma.  flavor is loaded with sweet sticky fruits(fresh squeezed purple grapes, plum, raisins, berries) tons of dark malts(chocolate, caramel).  amazing balance with some mild bittering hops in finish but this beer is clearly malt mania.  quite perfect actually. full bodied.  a real meal.
Pours brownish amber, dark fruits, caramel, molasses, roasted malts, little coffee, little hops, harsh alcohol finish?

poures a dark mahogany brown with a thick off white head.. Coffee and sweet dark roast in the aroma, toffee and caramel as well.
Slight anise/liqorice in the flavour backed by raisin fruit and dark roast body. Slightly sticky alc. finish. Very good.
Cask at Redlight.  I missed the beeruption, but saw the devastating effects.  Dark brown pour with a white head.  Very sweet caramel malts.  Almost a sweet berry flavor.  Not bad.

On cask at Redlight.  After taking a shower in this beer due to the extreme pressure exploding from the cask, causing a geyser rivaling Old Faithful, I sucked some of the sticky and sweet goodness from my arms to come up with this review.  Thanks to Redlight for giving me a story for years to come.  My first beer shower.  Color is dark amber with a thick foam white head.  Taste is sweet brown sugar and a slight bitterness.  Good beer, but I do not advise bathing in it.  It is very sticky.
On tap at Red Light.Poured dark with a nice khaki head.Malty, bready kinda sweet nose.Flavor was cookies and toffee.Pretty solid.
Had on a gravity keg at Redlight Redlight. Poured a golden amber color, thick head. Flavor was sticky pine, just a hint of orange sweetness, but mostly hoppy. Not a huge fan.

(10/16/08) Bottle at friends house in Philadelphia. Hazy dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of lots of malt and caramel, a bit of cookies, a bit of alcohol and some vinous fruity notes. Sweet malty flavor with caramel, some dark fruits (plums notes, some grapes) and a bitter dry finish with some slightly herbal hops, a light citric touch and a bit of alcohol. Medium to full-bodied. Really interesting stuff. I like it.

Sample at the Columbus Ratebeer gathering at ogglethorps 11/20/08: This Altbier is a pale amber-orange color with a medium and creamy beige head that recedes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Malty aroma with notes of dark fruit and hops. Medium-bodied with flavors of malt, molasses and hops. Warming alcohol is evident at times. The finish is full and malty with a bittersweet malt and hops aftertaste. Another enjoyable Alt from this brewer.

Tasting at Brewtopia.  Cloudy reddish pour wtih a very small head.  aroma is really  malty with some caramel, toffee, and sweet fruit.  Flavor is again very malty.  Caramel and toffee are everywhere/.  Smooth and enjoyable without a doubt!
great bottle,  red brown colored pour, aroma of strong malts, flavor is malty with a big floral, perfumed note on a dry bitter finish

Pours a muddy reddish brown with little to no head.  Aroma is sweet malt and alcohol, but mostly malt.  This is such a malt heavy sweet complex beer, the first sip literally made me say woo!  This beer is all about the malt and it does malt very well.  Sweet and bready, with a twinge of bitter backend and a nice alcohol bite.  This was a really nice beer.

Pours a very dark ruby brown in color with no head forming on the pour.  Another beer in Clean out the designated beer fridge ’08.  Smell is very toffee like with a shit ton of caramel malts.  Taste is even more of the toffee and caramel malts.  Make no mistake this is a dark, smooth beer.  Very well done.  This is something that I could drink a whole bunch of.  Very nice.

Pours a very dark brown body and is nearly opaque. Prunes, brown sugar, pecans and cinnamon mingle in the aroma. The flavor is nicely malty, but falls a bit flat of the aroma’s promise. Tasty beer, though.

Poured from awesome swingtop bottle into a cylinder glass. Dark sepia color, very hazy and opaque. Two fingers of creamy tan head, good retention and decent lacing.

Aroma is earthy cocoa and dried dark fruit. Slight metallic twang, probably from the heaviness of the water used.

Caky brown malt and figs make up a sweetness that washes over the front of the palate. Then a very earthy hop bitterness tears right through the flavor profile. The bitterness lingers and melds with the slight metallic note from the aroma. 

Mouthfeel is pretty good, carbonation is appropriate, body is medium-full without a trace of wateriness, no trace of alcohol.

A nice, well-balanced, thick, tasty German beer.

(Bottle).  Aroma is grassy and herbal, and also alcohol.  Color a beautiful mahogany, with a large creamy tan head.  Flavor is sweet, licorice and caramel, notes of bitterness and alcohol.  Well-brewed, but the flavor is not altogether pleasant.

Damn this is good beer.  Smells sweet, hints of plum.  Pours dark reddish brown with a thin head. Medium hop flavor with undlying sweetness.  Finishes up with a sour note which balances it out nicely.  Full body, leaves a stickiness behind.  Amazing beer, each taste presents something new.  Very complex.

Dark cherry red pour with a fluffy khaki head.  Sweet and malty aroma - overripe fruit: plum, date, fig, cherry, apple.  Some alcohol in the background.  Slightly toasty and nutty, some cinnamon and vanilla way in the back.  Flavor gives way to much less sweetness and much more hoppiness than I ever expected from the aroma.  Interesting and complex, with big caramel malts and a little bit of chocolate.  Silky in the mouth, with an oily residue.  I bought this after looking through beer-buddy Zeswafts higher ratings - thanks for the indirect recommendation.

Poured a nice reddish-brown with a tannish head. Had a smokey-molasses aroma. The beer was very well balanced with nice malty sweetness coupled with a hoppy finish. My first taste left a full, oily finish. This is a truly complicated beer that could be enjoyed a second time.

Crushed with Jakebra, and bought randomly.  Nose is similar to Bell’s Third Coast Old.  More barleywine tendencies than anything.  A complex, perplexing brew that gets better with each sip.  Confused but pleased, aight?

Pours amber with a decent head. Aroma of caramel, spicy and earthy hops. Some sweetness, solid bitterness at the end. Alcohol comes through a little

Pours amber with a decent head. Aroma of caramel, spicy and earthy hops. Some sweetness, solid bitterness at the end. Alcohol comes through a little.

Poured from a 11.2oz swing-top bottle and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a murky, rudy brown with a thin head of tan foam that slightly lasted.  The aroma of the beer was made up of super sweet toffee and caramel, brown sugar, a touch of chocolate, and also some dark fruits.  Very malty and barley wine-like.  The flavor was heavy on the caramel, while also containing notes of fruit, dates, and some mildly bitter roast.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied with a light stickiness.  Light carbonation.  A nice, malty drink.  Not overly sweet.  Decent.
Extremely sweet...almost sticky and syrupy.  Aroma and flavor display brown sugar, caramel, toffee, maple and dark fruit.  Raisin-like color with a small khaki head.  Hides the 8.5% well.

Bottle, and I almost want to give it extra points for such a cool bottle.  Deep amber brown pour with fluffly little tan head.  Smells like burnt sugar, malt, caramel, molasses, and a surprising little hop kick.  Notes of licorice, all the malty goodness described above, and some hops.  Not very yeasty.  Reminiscent of a barley wine.  Solid.

Kick ass bottle @ Maproom, so I needed to taste an Alt, why not! Bright dark amber w/ creamy finger of pale tan foam. Aroma of grassy hops & sticky caramel. Light, mildly sticky feel. Flavours are well-balanced w/ a light herbal spiciness. Overall not something that wowed me but a soild brew.

Pours cloudy brown with a large tan head.  Nose is molasses/sugary.  Flavor is surprisingly peppery, along with the heavy malt/molasses flavor.  Also raisin and floral hops.  Oily and syrupy mouthfeel.  Pretty good.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a tan head. Smells like a bowl of oatmeal with brown sugar and nuts. Sweet and burnt brown sugar flavor with a hint of licorice. Warming alcohol and a hoppy finish. great at room temp. B

Deep, dark brown, ruby. Compact, tan head, sticky lace. Deep. strong malty aroma, molasses, dark bread, caramel, hint of oxidaton. Medium full body, lucsious malts, nuts (reminds me of an vintage harvest ale) very nice in mouth, soft, bit sticky as warms, hints of oxidation in taste but not too horrible. Hops come through, adding nice flavor and backing bitterness. Would love to try a really fresh sample for this has a bit f age I presume. But a gem of a brew.
roasty, earthy, brown, hazy, aminimal head, light sweetness, very bitter, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter,

Pours a syrupy dark brown color with red highlights. Medium to small sized creamy head. Nose is toffee and smoked salmon skin. Some soy sauce too. Mouthfeel is on the heavier side but comes out extremely well balanced. Finish is lingering and smokey and is easily quaffable. Taste is sweet and malty, there is a definite hop presence and a pretty good bitter after component. Some honey and chocolate in the flavor too. Well made and tasty but does not blow me away.

Bottle. Pours deep rubt brown with a beige head. Malty aroma with carmael and licorice, as well as some earthy notes. Medium body. Flavor is again very much caramel malt and licorice, with some toasty, soy and brown sugar as well. Nice.

Finally a high-gravity and highly hopped German bier.  My love for Uerige’s other biers notwithstanding, this bier is fantastic  Darker than the normal Alts, the aroma is malty and alcoholic. Make sure you don’t drink this too cold.
Bottle. Interesting shape and jazz.  Pours a amber copper body.  Aroma/flavor is sweet chocolate malt, nuttiness, dark fruit, raisin.  A solid beer but pricey even at 8.5%

A clear dark brown beer with a thick dissipating light moka head. A nice aroma of licorice, dried dark fruits and warming alcohol. In mouth, loads of licorice, warming alcohol, burned coffee beans, lingering in mouth. Rich bodied. Shared with Probstk. Thanks Karl for sharing this with me.

33cl bottle, a very interesting flip top bottle- pours with a light carbonation, swamp water hazy brown, very slight head/lacing. Very ripe dark fruit/ prune aroma, smells candy sweet. Taste is ripe dark fruits/ prune/ dried fruit, slightest hop presence, trace of molasses, thick malt body. Alcohol stays hidden.This beer needs a food pairing to keep the palate from being tired of it all.

bottle.. dark ruby pour ,thin tan head.aroma of dark fruit ,annis molasses.and nuts. flavor is a complex mix of figs, molasses,licorice and burnt sugar. medium bodied finishes dry and a little bitter ,slick and delicious.

This is particularly good. The aroma is very sweet, with hints of dark malt, molasses, and light floral notes. The color is a nice deep brown with a good white head. The taste is particularly the best part, a huge bouquet of flavors emerges, of course the beer has a big malty flavor with bits of licorice, dried fruit, and sticky roasted malt. But the dryness and the bitterness are what make this beer amazing, this beer has a lot of hop flavoring, its no hopbomb but the spicy bitterness of the hops dominates much of the tongue with this beer. While an alcohol sting is present, this beer remains very smooth and easy to drink. I will be buying this again.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 (GERMAN)  Pours a hazy amber color with fizzy white head. There is a malty, alcohol aroma with a zesty mouthfeel. The taste is of dark fruit, molasses, and caramel. And the finish is super dry and by far one of the most bitter beers ive tasted !!!!  This was more then i expected, a pleasant suprise. One other thing the bottle is very unique.  Do yourself a favor and get some !!!!   :)

J. Betskis Raleigh, NC 5/16/08. Cool F-in bottle with an even cooler glass. Deep brown color with ruby hues. Soda poppy head and carbonation, aroma of toasted malt and honey. Flavors of dark fruit, licorice and a good sweet-bitter balance, all of these flavors helped to mask the alc. burn until the aftertaste. I want a case of these.

11,2 fl. oz. bottle via dkachur (thanks!) shared with Lubiere, served cool in a tulip glass.
App.:  Dark ruby-copper, tiny light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Huge dripping gobs of raisins and figs, molasses and licorice, minty herbals, light wood, nuts and alcohol.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft carbonation, somewhat oily.
  
Flav.:  Lots of raisins, burnt sugar, dark molasses, minty herbals, licorice, lightly salty; somewhat sweet and quite bitter, leaves a vinous, fruity, licorice-like aftertaste with good duration.

Huge beer, small bottle.

A cold pour produces a slow rising frothy head that reaches its peak at three fingers then sits there like a stubborn muledeer.  Lacing is lasting, sticky, and fluffy. Aromas of sweet malted butter and darkfruit. A dark nut brown color emerges. Full nectar with good carbonation that thickens up like heavy cream on the palate. Sweet upfront turning bitter on a dime. Flavors of plumb, nectarine, maple, strict peachpit bittering. Finishes dry with lingering flavors.

Cloudy, near opaque brown pour with a thin off-white head. Malty, bready nose with a hop undercurrent. Flavor is rich and very much like a barley wine: alcohol and malt with a fruity sweetness that is slightly overshadowed by the hoppiness. Its an interesting balance with caramel and roasted malts competing with an earthy hallertau hop thing. Very nice.

Pours a murky dark brown with auburn highlights, ahs a doughy and somewhat fruity nose, and you can immediately make out the style.  This is one of those beers that essentially has to be drank at the proper temperature to truly appreciate all it has to offer.  The alcohol is very present but in a warming way, and not a hot on the top of the mouth kinf of way, slightly heavy mouthfeel, with lots of sweet dark fruits and bit of a caramelized nuttiness, blended with bittersweet raisins.  Very nice.

Dark velvet borwn body; pillowy half-inch head that settles to a solid brown--intimidating! Tremendous balance of malt, hop and fruity yeasts--pleasantly alluring.... warm, smooth and full-bodied--more like a porter or imperial stout in the mouthfeel... little alcohol to note... coffee and stout-like smokiness that rushes to the throat... malt is most prevalent and balanced with creamy esthers... in reading the "commercial description" I can see my expectations were pleasantly surprised... a bit challenging by mid-glass, but overall a warming brew--and at $75 a case, probably not an economic choice when seeking out doppelbocks (which I falsely thought this was)-- weighing that in, still an enjoyable beer to sit with, stare at, savor...

Cask firkin at Capital Ale House. Almost an opaque dark brown. Malt dominated aroma with some sour overtones. Dark roast malt, raisin and sweet caramel flavors. Cramy full mouthfeel with little carbonation. Hop bitterness last well into finish.

Cask at Cap. Ale - Midlothian for their opening.  A great beer, nice dark pour with a great aroma of heavy malts, caramel and dark fruit accents.  Very smooth taste, again with the dark fruit accents.  Ending was very nice and smooth.

Thanks DrBayern (Hey Matt) Pours a deep ruby from 11.2 oz bottle.  Formed medium size off white foamy head.. Aroma was of sweet malted caramels.  Flavour was of a smooth bitterness, hops, malts, roasted nuts.  What a pleasant suprise, very good beer from our friends in Germany.  I would love to try it on tap.  Really reminds me of a Barleywine stlye beer, superb!

Mahalo Matt, you were right.  ;)

text: Dark amber with a thin off white head.  Strong citrus and malt aroma.  Flavor is citrusy hops,  caramel,  toffee,  celery, dark fruit,  brown sugar.  Slightly bitter finish,  no hint of the abv.  Pretty fun.
Pour is hazed brownish amber with a thin brown head...smell is caramel and lightly toasty...taste is lightly sweet and toasty with a strange malty bitterness at the end...lightly alcoholic...

Wood cask @ Beer Table. Poured brown with a hint of reddishness into a small Uerige straight sided glass, subdued tan head. Nose is malty, hints of alcohol, caramel, toffee, dark fruits. Taste is sweet, caramelized brown sugar, dark fruits, with an almost subdued hoppy bitterness in the finish. Definitely a delicious beer, and a very unique take on a traditional german style.

Going into this expecting something barley wine-ish probably isnt the best way to do it.  unless you pay attention to the part of the commercial description that reads "Germanys INTREPRETATION."  That said, it was a pleasure to drink!  Like a hoppy doppel bock/barley wine sort of concoction.  Definitely unique, and something Im not sure I could have handled a few years ago.  I guess getting older has its benefits afterall!  Love the bottle.

Wooden pin @ the Beer Table. It has a brown color. The aroma is wood/bark, faint alcohol, and it surrounded by light dark fruits. Taste is lightly syrupy sugar with dark fruits and light prunes.  It finishes with a bitter finish,  It really nice and very un-German.  Its easy drinking yet the bitter finish gives it some real heft.  There is an aspects of sweet prune in the finish as well.  Very nice and I am glad I got to try this pin as opposed to the bottles.

text: Clear mahogany with a creamy tan colored head. Big fruity melanoidan aroma with raisin, plum, caramel malt, floral hops. Soft, fruity and alcoholic in flavor. More bitter than most German Dopplebocks Ive had. Candy like in flavor, similar to a Dopplebock but perhaps a little lighter in body with some tanginess and a more pronounced hop flavor.

It was a great beer....almost seemed like a dopplebock and a english barley wine had kids.....It was smooth and malty....almost like and impereal dopplebock....quite a bit different then....most alt beers I have had

Excellent doppelbock style.  Beer was rich dark and roasty.  Flavors of caramel, roasted malt, and tofee were smooth.  Acquired at a local beer restaurant.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 bottled 04/18... not sure what that means. rich hazy amber/brown color with a small khaki head that leaves light spotty lacing. smells like raisins and skunky hops mixed with sweet malt, molasses, wood and grass. it tastes like regular ovaltine... chocolate, vanilla, raisins and sweet grains. a nice dry bitter grassiness offsets the sweet (but not cloying) palate. aftertaste is of grassy and skunky hops.  medium to full body with soft carbonation and a slick smooth texture.  7/4/8/4/16/3.9

 on tap at papago... ruby tinted brown shade of black with a huge puffy off white head. additional aromas of fresh cherries and maple syrup added to the prior review. lots of spice and a hint of alcohol creep in on the palate as it warms. any sugar previously tasted from the bottle is no issue and really nowhere. roasty bitterness and fresh hoppy dryness really clean it up nicely. full rich body with a luscious creamy mouth feel...8/4.5/8/4.5/17/4.25
Bottled. Medium ruby in color. Spiced dark fruit aroma. Dry and yeasty flavored with a bit of raisin. Dark and fruity rule the day in this beer.

Pours a cloudy brown almost cocoa color with a thin beige head.  Week aroma that is malty with some hops.  A little watered down for my taste.  ABV well hidden with a nice balance of maltiness and hops.

3-2-08 bottle shared at tasting 
Dirt brown pour with a nice light simple head.  Smell is subtle and malty and a hint smokyish.  Taste is caramel and spiced.  Thin average palate.  A hint watery. Reminds me of a dopplebock or perhaps watered down scotch. Hmmmm.

bottle shared courtesy of JohnathanL.  Thanks!

Pours a light muddy brown color with light head.  Smell is thin and caramel like malt mostly.  Taste is toasty, creamy caramel, with a tart edge to it, in the way an Oktoberfest might be.  Somewhat thin, but smooth.  Very drinkable but didnt stand out too much.  Still enjoyable.
Bottle. Nice dark color. Warm brown with vanilla colored head. Smells of dried fruits. Excellent flavor, taste of roasted malt. Love this beer

Bottle.  Poured an opaque brown with a moderate off-white head, good lacing.  Sweet raisin full malt aroma.  Vry malt, sweet with litle roast character, fruity.  Linginer bitter sweet taste, medium bodied.

Pours dark chocolate with a beautiful creamy beige head.  Sweet, dusty, sour, malty aroma.   Intense dark malt flavor, coffee, nutty, bready with a good amount of hops and some nice low bitterness.  Quite sweet & very rich.  Nice full mouthful.   For all the different flavors its really nicely balanced and smooth.   Tastes like a traditional ale mixed with a kolsch.

33cl bottle.  Vigorous pour, somewhat hazy deep brown liquid topped with some dense tan foam that fades to a thin layer leaving behind some very nice lacing.  Aroma is a big blast of dark malts, a good bit of toffee and some nice almost piney hops.  Flavor falls a little short of the aroma, was expecting much more malt and got a lot more hop and a little hint of alcohol.  Damn smooth mouthfeel for something pushing 9%.

Oh I really like this. Aroma is so heavy in melanoidins theyre branching off into all kinds of dark territory. Rum raisin, fruitcake, plummy rum, cocoa. Deep purple color, light carbonation which meant no head, but it did leave a very fine if sparse lacing in the glass. Rich melanoidins in the flavor, chewy with chocolate toffees and a date like fruitiness. Long rich bittersweet finish.  Mildly warming. Smooth if slightly slick mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogany with moderate beige head. The aroma is very fruit, with raspberry, dark cherry, plum, a little bit of raisin, with a faint spicy yeast quality. The flavor is packed with spicy bitterness, and is rather coarse and almost tannic. Once past that, the fruity and caramel malts jump out. The finish is dry and woody. Decent enough drink, this.

Bottled poured into a Kölsch/Altbier glass.  With the cylindrical shape of the glass & the dark murky color of the beer this could be a core sample from the bottom of the Mississippi River.  The head medium to small and creamy looking.  UDS has a huge bouquet of dark fruits like plums along with licorice and spicy hops.  The malt insists on notice as well.  The taste is malty and sweet.  Raisin and timber reside in an extremely soft feel.  This is by far the best example of an altbier Ive ever had.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma is sweet.  Smells malty, with notes of nuts, slight funk, toffee, and a little yeast.  Poured chestnut brown in color with a medium-sized, creamy tan head that lasted throughout.  Good lacing.   Hazy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is a bit sweet.  Tastes very malty, with notes of herbs, wood, nuts, salt, and something I cannot identify.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty finish.

Red chestnut body with a huge thick beige head; Warm deep serious nose with lots of hidden treasures, green fresh touch way back; Big full serious body, balanced, complex moving into a long interesting finish with soft full and sharp deep notes. Great beer!

Aroma is touches of cocoa, nutty, and bock-ish with malty/grainy element and a touch of hops.  
Taste has hints of hops and is bittersweet with a grainy and dull copper essence to it.  
I like this.

11.2 oz bottle with swing top, 05/07.  Pours a dark ruby with 2 cm off-white head that is mostly diminishing.  Aroma is full of dark fruits, mostly raisins.  Flavor is well balanced with dark fruits, maybe more dates now, and bitter hops and some citrus.  Medium body, no carbonation, very light lacing, some alcohol noted as it warms.  Nice beer and drinkable.

Wow, I was warned this was going to be a super alt and it certainly is. Pours reddish black with a thin white head. Aroma is heavy caramel malt, molasses, and roasted malt. aroma is just overpowering. Doppelbock aroma on steroids. Thick malt taste with caramel malt, roasted malt, and molasses. Thick powerful and different, thanks to Solan for suggesting it.

[942-20071207] 11.2floz. Sweet boozy malt aroma. Clear, dark brown red body with a medium-lasting creamy light tan head. Dark malty booze flavour has nice rich raisin characteristics. Medium-full body. Good.

Beautiful sweet aroma, strong carmel malt notes. Taste is sweet but balanced with a lingering hoppy bitterness. Notes of toffee, chocolate, and burnt sugar, with herbal hops. Very complex flavor but perhaps a little more bitter than I would prefer. Overall quite good.

11.2 oz bottle. 06/04.  Murky brown with a puffy beige head.  Nose of toasty caramel and cola, bready underneath.  Medium body with a sharp carb tang.  Taste is burnt caramel and orange peel, grassy, then gin and grapefruit.  Lingering sweetness, light drying.  Even after 3-1/2 years this stuff is kick ass.

A 11.2 oz bottle with a bottled on date stamped on the lable. The beer poured a dark rube body with a small head that disapates quickley. Smell of roasted malts and strong hops. A coffee and toffee. A coating mouth feel and good carbonation, no lacing to speak of.

Single Beer!

11.2 oz traditional long neck bottle with a purple lable and swing top.

It pours an ok head that falls into almost no head. Color is ruby and brown. 

Smell is heavy with burnt sugar, it also has fig and dark tangy fruit smells. 

Taste is malty with a big burnt sugar taste and ends with sweet bitter hoppiness. Its fruity undertones have been aged, so they are not as prominent. 

Mouthfeel is excellent and smooth

Definetly another beer I would find fresh to appreciate more of what it has to offer, but this isn t bad at all.

Brown, creamy top . Neat looking alt . Pleasant medium bitter nose with clean malty spectrum. Sherry, woody alcoholic nose . Medium bodied, well refined. Alcohol definitive is present. Maybe more than I would wish for. Solid kraft werk .

33 cl, bottled 05 07. Barely translucent mahogany with a large head that settles in for the duration. Spicy molasses, raisins, and cocoa aroma. Big chocolate molasses front fades into a nicely balanced dance with some grassy-herb hops that finish the deal with a slightly bitter, floral, and dry-roasted flavor. Dangerously easy to drink. Medium-heavy bodied and smooth with a dry finish.

Pours brown-red with a half-finger white head. A good deal of roasted malt in the aroma, alongside a bunch of caramel and a little bit of chocolate. Some alcohol comes across, hot and leathery. Great, heavily-malted flavor rich with sticky toffee and a lightly-charred roastiness. The alcohol is lost among the bitter chocolate and espresso finish. Like a roasted doppelbock. Creamy mouthfeel.
Tasted at SIB. Pours a hazy dark copper with a firm off-white head. Full body. Kind of like an IPA for malt. Molasses, roasty malt.

Bottled. Had dark red brown color, nice 
medium head. I could smell caramel and honey notes. So far so good. Then the taste--at first i thought the glass had soap residue or something, so i switched glasses. But the next time I realized in was almost like the flavor of rose petals. This flavor didnt mesh with the other flavors in the beer, and overall really detracted from the taste. I was rather disappointed. The alcohol was present, and possibly made the rosy/soapy flavors stand out even more.

Bottled.  Poured deep murky brown with a moderate cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up deeper, alcohol-laced caramels and chocolate notes with brown sugar and light molasses.. rather thick and malty with a bit of herbal and fruity hoppage in there.. warm nose.  The flavor added some sweeter cookies to the chocolate and caramel at the core.. herbal bitterness was higher, and the alcohol was warm on the back-end.. quite tasty.  Medium-plus bodied with a long bitter impression on the finish.. nice cookie and caramel sweetness back there, too.. well-balanced, but perhaps a bit too bitter on the back.

Bottle. Aroma has a moderate cookie note, a light herb note, and a moderate earth note, with smells of toffee, brown sugar, dark dried fruit and alcohol to back them up. Head is thin, creamy white, has good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter, then the long finish is lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, creamy/syrupy and has a soft carbonation. It finishes lightly dry. The flavor had and unusual mix of sweet and bitter with a drying finish. Slightly warmed, this makes an excellent after dinner drink.

Bottle. Pours like a stout. Black with brown head, long lasting and thick, with a good amount of lacing. Aroma of pepper and raisins. Very hoppy taste when compared to the maltiness of the aroma. Still, a background of raisin and toffee. Interesting twist on one of my favorite styles.

11.2 oz swing cap bottle. Poured a reddish/brown with a very slight off white head that just barely coated the entire body of the beer.Malty aroma of raisins, sugar, wood, pineapple, honey, and bread. Medium to full bodied with lots of lively carbonation and a very dry palate. Flavor has an overall soapy flavor that distracts from the other flavors. Notes of wood, peat, brown sugar, malts and tons of alcohol for only being 8.5%. Pleasant but I was hoping for more.

In short: Weird perfumy floral malty beer of some kind.  Intriguing. 
How: Bottle, almost one year old.
The look: Cloudy copper-brown body with a short-lived beige head.
In long: Aroma is unusually floral for an Albier, almost perfume.  Very yeasty beer with a bubblegum aroma and flavour (purple grapes bubblegum to be more precise).  Rather sweet with .  Liquorice, caramel and lost of spicy hard-candies.  A little peppermint and a little medicinal flavour (cough syrup?).  Really full body, sticky and resinous.  Strong but weird bitterness.  The hops came out as garden flowers (lilacs mainly) and a little piney.  I believe this was my first bottle of this well-known beer.  Certainly not what I expect from an Alt.  Was it because of the almost one-year of age but something just wasnt right here.  The potential was there but it was all over the place.  A weird beer through and through.  Looks great as a candlestick though and the only reason Id buy another bottle is to get a matching pair.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2008 Bottled 06-04.  Pours a hazy, muddy, deep garnet with a moderately-full, beige, creamy head; longevity is fair and lacing is plentiful.  Nose is great and rich; burnt brown sugar notes, toffee, caramellized dates, light wood notes, and some spicy, floral hops.  Flavor is much of the same with a moderate bitterness; burnt wood, burnt caramel, vanilla, molasses, date, and lightly floral/spicy hops.  Palate is nice with a moderately full body, a lively carbonation, and a silky smooth feel.  Finishes long and bittersweet with molasses, almost some chocolate, date, lingering spicy hop notes, with a bit of floral still there.  Takes the great attributes of a strong Alt and of a doppel and creates a great, unique beer.  Awesome, rich malt tones with a balancing hop presence.  I cant believe I waited so long to try this one, turned out to be one the best german beers Ive tried.

Pours a dark rawhide brown with half a thumbnail of tan head. The pour itself is subtle and coagulate like a dense barley wine. Creamy caramel aromas waft straight out of the bottle. Tastes are robust with roasted caramel, wood, big big malts, dark fruits, mild tobacco, and peanut brittle. Lingering alcohol toward the finish. Soft carbonation and full bodied. Flavors are strong up front, but peter out in the finish. I havent had too many Altbiers yet, but this had all the qualities of a good barley wine over anything else.

This was not an altbier if I have anything to do with it. Damn good, but not an altbier. Aroma was decent...dark fruit(?), burnt malt and must. Pour was as beautiful as a beer could get. Deep murky brown with not much movement and a 2 finger tan head.  Looked like a river at night time. Taste was very strong and pronounced. Heavy on the malt, very thick mouthfeel (almost like a milkshake) and very alcoholic. Burns the throat at swallow. Some hoppiness in the aftertaste. The commercial description is dead on...does taste like a barleywine. Just older and dirtier.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
11.2 oz brown swing top bottle poured into a shaker pint. Hazy dark copper, appeared to be bottle conditioned. Two fingers of fine white bubbled head.
Lots of malt in the aroma, some noble hops, and a little alcohol.
Deep malty flavor, plenty of sweetness. Caramel/molasses.
Nice dose of hop bitterness to balance it out. Medium to full bodied.
A really unique beer, very drinkable.

Hugely disappointing. I cant believe the beer in this bottle was what was supposed to be in there. Smelled and tasted like a dopplebock that was overhopped and had gotten old. Taste was sweet carmely malt with lots of old rubbery hops. Color was a murky red brown. Their regular altbier is fantastic,this was ugly
Brown and slightly hazy w/ tan lasting head; maly aroma/ fresh grain; stron malt flavor; creamy feel; malty alcohol finish w/ a touch of hops.

11.2oz bottle. Served in Grandpas pils glass. Very rich aroma of brown sugar & prunes along with some earthy notes. Very much a dopplebock. Very dark red color, nearly brown with a smallish cream colored head and good clarity. Thick bodied. Taste is dark caramel, mild roast, herbal & earthy hops, plums/prunes, vanilla, and blackstrap molasses. Very smooth, despite the strong flavors. Nice moderately bitter finish with some nice malty flavors, but no real residual sweetness. Easy drinking beer despite being 8.5%.

Deep dark red/brown with a frothy head with long retention. A moderate aroma of sweet bread and molasses. Holly Crap! Be carful if you gulp when you drink. I don’t think I was ready for that. Bitter at first then finishes sweet and goes down Aunt Jemima. What it lacks in complexity it makes up for in bitter, burnt, syrup, sweet and a lot of it.

7/14/05 330ml. side by side with Uerige Alt. Dark brown with small quick dissipating head. Aroma consist of Vanilla malt and alcohol. Palate was a little too viscous and had too much alcohol. I did not think more was better in this case.

Poured a cloudy brown color with a thin tan head which quickly faded away, there was some mild lacing.  Aroma was mainly malty some roasted some sweet.  I really can no describe the as caramel like , but it was sweet.  Flavor was rich with roasted malt note with  a nice spice at the end.  Full bodied.

The color was murky medium/dark orange/brown.  The head was medium bodied, creamy, frothy, and light biege.  The aroma was pleasant with scents of root beer, spices, and sweet malt.  The flavor was alcohol, spicey, waxy at the back of the mouth, hops, sweet malt, and basement must.  The palate was nicely carbonated.  The finish was waxy and warm.

Pours a murky reddish brown with a nice creamy tan head. The aroma is sweet, caramel, raisins, bubblegum, alcohol, very very nice.  Warm alcohol, flavor is much more toned down than nose, earthy rich malty, caramel, slight hop wax at the back of the mouth. Full smooth palate with a noticeable carbonation and pleasant warmth. Delicious. If only the flavor had lived up to the aroma.

The 11.2 ounce bottle poured a clear deep mahogany (reddish brown) colored beverage with a modest creamy off-white head that was mostly diminishing but left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was strong and fruity with notes of plum, raisins, caramel and just a hint of aged leather. The body was medium-full with soft carbonation and a smooth creamy texture. The flavor started out moderately bitter with just a hint sweetness at the edge. The finish was long with a bit of alcohol warmth in the chest and the bitterness mellowed nicely.
Poured a dark amber-chestnut body with a creamy off-white dome and great lacing. Sweet, caramel, chocolate, fruity nose.  Very complex.  Bold, well-balanced and extraordinarily awesome!

crimson red body with a creamy off white head that leaves nice lacing as it sits.i pick up cotton candy,smoke,grapefruit,and caramel malts in the aroma.flavor is of smoke,cotton candy,apples,grapefruit,and caramel.

I just spent quite a while typing up a very detailed review but then my browser messed up and erased it.  I dont feel like typing it all out again.  The most unique thing about this beer I thought was that the aroma smelled most like some kind of womans hand soap - very flowery and fruity but in a way that reminded me of soap.  Odd, but pleasant.

I think this was bottled in 2004?  pours a dark ruby brown, fairly clear with an off-white head.  Aroma is a pretty complex mix of raspberries, raisins and plums with some caramel, french bread and white chocolate notes.  Theres a slight leather note poking through, which actually works well and adds to the aroma.  Taste isnt quite as good to me, but it still has a lot going on.  Caramel and raisin flavors abound with some bitter citrus, almost grapefruit flavor thrown in.  Finishes becomes a bit dry and woody, with a slightly burnt aftertaste.  These hops have definitely held up well and pretty much dominate the flavor and finish.  The beers just shy of thick, but it lacks creaminess.  Just a bit too slick and oddly still too carbonated.  Great aroma, but the taste isnt quite as nice.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 Dark brown poured a thin white head you can tase the alcohol on this one almost like a malt wisky (might grab another one and let it age )

Large tan head, medium amber hue. Aroma is predominantly sweet caramel and raisins with just a hint of dough. Flavor is initially bitter then more sweet. Medium mouthfeel and a bit of warming in the finish.
Bottle, Uber Taven.  Foggy brown mud color, with a thin white head.  Aroma is caramel, light alcohol, raisin.  Taste is light alcohol, dried fruit, chocolate, old coffee, slight nutty character.

Bottle courtesy of Plucier: Poured a dark brown color beer with a huge foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of chocolate and dry raisins is enjoyable but definitely not what I was expecting. Taste is comprised of sweet malt with some nice notes of chocolates and dry fruits with a somewhat dry finish. Well done overall but definitely not what I was expecting for and Alt but again it is style that I dont really know too well..

bottle via trade with dragonstout.  Thanks for the bonus.  Pours an odd light brown with a stable firm 2 finger off white head.  The nose is sweet and strong.  This is very malty and sweeter than I had expected.  I dont know if I would go as far as the commercial description and push this into the realm of German barleywine, but it is certainly more complex and bigger in taste than average German fair.

Poured murky pond water which subsided into a nice dark ruby red color with an off white head. Aroma of cherries and alcohol. Taste of sweet malt, light hops, and fruit with an alcohol burn finish. You can taste every bit of the 8.5% alcohol. Very different and not my type of brew.
xxx Really cool bottle for starters.  good beer, never got me too excited, but i cant say anything negative about it either.

330 at the Seattle International Beerfest. Pours deep murky brown with dense moussy tan head. Big roasty leafy nose. Bold attack--big body, firm carb, aggressive flavors. Deep earth and roast and wet leaves, clingy, burny finish. Wonderful stuff.

pours copper with fizzy khaki head.  aroma is floral, herbal, funky, and sweet caramel malt.  taste is a little funky with lots o euro hop and sweet caramel and toffee malt.  finish has a very good tangy bitterness.  good stuff but this is nothing like any alt ive ever had.

Murky brownish pour with frothy off-white head is fairly transparent.  Palate is a little thin, although with nice carbonation and texture.  Flavor is one of the most unique Ive experienced:  chewy malty start has a yeasty funk too it before a large amount of European hops dry it out.  An engrossing quality takes over as the brew is enjoyed and the comparison to a barleywine is apt.  Worth hunting out for it uniqueness.

Cool flip top bottle looks rather gothic.  Code 0509.  Pours clear orange brown.   Nose is abundant sweet malt cookie, bread, licorice, and alcohol .. nice.  Sweet carmel/toffee flavors are contrasted with the tar/pine and alcohol.  Im enjoying this.
Bottle. Hazy copper color with a medium head. Aroma of burnt caramel and grass. Taste was caramel, raisins, toffee, and just a bit of sour malt vinegar. Heavy bodied. A little warm. Pretty nice.

bottle, thanks holdenn for the sample. pours murky brown with off white head. nose of english toffee, bread, nuts, and wet grains. flavor is sweet, nutty, bready, raisins, caramally. alcohol is well hidden. a tasty beer but it just doesnt interest me.

Bottle from Kingdom Liquors Brandon, Fl. Pours a clear dark amber with a small long lasting light tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, a touch of roasted malt, and light spicy hops. Taste is very bitter up front then lends way to sweet caramel, dark fruit, and light spicy german hops. Medium full mouthfeel with a solid bitterness and slight alcohol warmth. Different but very good.

Pours dark amber with a tan head. Aroma of various dark fruits along with a bit of secondary hop aromas. Flavor of brown sugar, bready malts, herbs, and alcohol toward the finish. Nice thick brew. Too bad this costs so much.

The aroma is sweet with plums, prunes, raisins, earth, herbal hops, rubber, and yeast. The appearance is maroon/brown with a small but persistent head. The flavor is acidic with an astringent bitterness and a mishmash of dark fruit flavor along with earth, butterscotch, and paper. The palate is thick and smooth and probably the  bes thing about this beer. At first I thought the alcohol was well hidden but it does develop and overpower especially towards the finish. Overrated but its got a mighty nice bottle.

kkerarn you got it right by my taste!11.2oz flip-top bottle. Dark amber with a thin tan head. Malty aroma with some brown sugar, caramel and hops. Some malty sweetness initially, but quickly gives way to floral hops along with some herbs, peat and alcohol. Very unique.

11.2oz flip-top bottle. Dark amber with a thin tan head. Malty aroma with some brown sugar, caramel and hops. Some malty sweetness initially, but quickly gives way to floral hops along with some herbs,  peat and alcohol. Very unique.
Bottle - Dark amber/copper color with white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, grass.  Malted flavor, with caramel, raisins, hops.  Warming alcohol finish.  Full bodied.

Bottle from ross. Thanks. Pours a dark brown amber with a healthy white head. Nose is raisns, musty yeasy, sweet malts, plums, fruitcake and light hoppy aroma. Flavor is sweet, but not cloyingly so. Definite hoppy bitterness noted in the finish. A nice alt, this is a very close to a light barleywine or old ale with a disitinct hoppy presence. In any case, its pretty nice.
Dar brown body with quickly fading head.  Sweet malt nose with hint of hops.  Bitter hop body, tangy with a slightly harsh finish.

Bottle shared with brewfiend. Pours a deep chestnut brown with an off-white fast fading head. Leaves behind a thin film and nice lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, molasses, maple syrup, pitted fruit and tobacco. Taste is medium body, sweet and a touch of hops in the finish with character of pepper and cloves. Nice looking bottle and label.
(bottle) Slightly hazy brown. Faint malt/alcohol aroma. Syrupy sweet, dark malt and dark fruits, alcohol in the finish. I found it a bit cloying.

super cloudy double-dark ruddy copper, with ruddy highlights.  head is tall thickish foamy medium tan.  aroma is sweet like dates, honey, and deep raosted pale malts.  almost smells like a mead.  flavor is sweet syrupy sticky malt, a little dry grassy flavor, some alcohol heat, then bitter leafy finish.

Out of happenstance, or perhaps karmic alignment, I find myself enjoying this beer as my 1700th rating on my 5th anniversary on RateBeer. Not quite a beer a day, but all in all, not a bad showing for my geographical location these days. Alcohol vapors. Rich and malty, with dusty grain and bitter resinous hops note. Has the characteristic Düsseldorfer Alt aroma - kind of earthy with some bit of funk that I cant put my finger on - mild but its there. Nice malt sweetness. Deep amber brown clear with medium off-white foamy lacing head, not quite creamy. Medium-heavy watery body, but theres a nice softness to it. Medium to light carbonation. Starts with medium-heavy malty sweetness. A bit of raisin and dark brown sugar, caramel. Good alcohol presence with some warming burn on the way down. The finish comes in with a nice bitter quality. Neither fruity or herbal, though there is a bitter nutty dryness to it that cuts the sweet malts and potentially a cloying sweetness that would otherwise persist. Theres a bit of herbal essence in the very end, leaving you with a dry bitterness on the tongue and a bit of sweetness on the sides. Heavy but a nice beer.
Sweet aroma, but the flavor has some solid hop bitterness that doesnt come through as much on the nose.  Velvety mouthfeel is very nice.

Pale amber color, fluffy white head.  A bit of a winey scent to it, sweet malts and caramel.  This is a tasty beer, tastes like candy.  Nice sweet malt, caramel flavors.  A little thin on the tongue, but overall very good.

Date: 3/28/2007
Serving: 11.2 oz flip-top bottle.
Event: Drinks with the team after work.
Location: Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio.
Tasting Notes
Aroma: Earthy, aged dark fruits, fermenting apples, some mustiness.
Appearance: Murky brown/amber color with a foamy beige head (good retention).  Remaining crown leaves some scant lacing.
Flavor: Caraml and chocolate malt with some fruit (pear and apples) and alcohol.  The finish is dry, roasty, and has a lingering bitterness (moderate in strength).  There is a warming and burning alchol sensation through the nose, so the 8.5% ABV is obviously there.
Palate: Medium to full body and smooth.
Overall: A solid altbeir with a nice complexity.

red orange color with creamy tan head.  some raisin and heavy malt aromas, with some orange background.  flavor of raisin, sour yellow cherries, with some carmel and lots and lots and lots of different malts.  delic. though

Drak opaque reddish brown with medium off-white head.   Aroma is rather malty with a slight sour hint.  Taste is unusual... rather apparently alcoholic and hoppy in a way I didnt expect, and this is not a bad thing. $4/11.2oz
95, are you kidding.  Malty crap if you as me. The worst part is that it looked good from the start and came in a sweet bottle.  Might as well be a malt liquor...PHEW!!!

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 330ML bottle via Flacoalto (THANKS!). Pours a dark reddish brown with an average sized beige head. Nose is oxidized and a little sour. Tastes like an oxidized barleywine. Lot of malts and hops, some acetone and warm alc bite on the finish. Dont care too much for this one.
heavy sherry/ port wine aroma and taste driven brew. hoppy and sweet. I guess thats how its rolling. but above all thathas a good aroma more drinkable warmer.

Poured a dark ruby or cherry color with a tan head.  Aromas cherries, strussel, and spicey hops.  The flavor was a bit much.  Really nothing like an altbier at all.  Very rich on the palate.  Cloying.

(33cl swing top bottle) Slightly hazy, chestnut-brown colour with a medium-sized foamy and quite persistent tanned head. Sweet toast-malty aroma with caramel, cinnamon and liquorice-spicy notes, also delicate but aromatic herbal hops and light fruity accents. Dark malt-character, slightly toasted and almost perfectly rounded up with spicy notes (cinnamon, liquorice, cough-syrup) and a delicate, subtle fruitiness; long and lasting initially sweet, later strong bitter hoppy finish. Very aromatic strong Alt, which tastes more like a Barley Wine. For me (being beer-socialized in Germany), it definitely lacks session-qualities, hence I prefer the normal Sticke (03.01.07).

From a swing top, narrow neck, embossed, uniquely shaped 11.2 oz. bottle with a bottling and freshness date on the neck label, sampled at a cool cellar temperature in a stange glass.

Poured a lightly hazy, reddish copper with a frothy, tight bubbly, foamy off-white head that settled slowly into a thin sudsy, fluffy, creamy lacing, small amount of ringed sticking.

Aromas of sweet roasted malts, a hint of caramel, a light fig and raisin fruitiness, earthy, herbal, and whiffs of spicy alcohol.

Good, even moderate carbonation and a crisp, dryish bitter, slick, chewy, creamy smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel.

Barley wine-like taste with a earthy, spicy, herbal hop bitterness, sweet roasted malts with a touch of sugar, a light caramel coffee, a ripe raisin fruitiness, earthy, spicy herbal hops with a nice lingering bitterness, the alcohol has a spicy warmth in the palate, and a dry, bitter, fruity, alcoholic, malty finish.

Another excellent Altbier from Uerige, definitely a sipper, but dangerously quaffable, a must try.

Bottle from Ledgers; nose of dark fruit, caramel malt, spices, and brown sugar; Brown with a medium tan head; flavor is hoppybitterness, along with caramel, spices, figs, and a nice bitter hop finish.

Fruity aroma with vanilla, dates, huge pilsy malt, and spicy hops; chewy body enveloping a medicinal, creamy, orange-peel and nut flavor; finishes nicely bitter, tart and flowery. Quite interesting, and very good.

Bottle.  Doppel Sticke has a very malty sweet aroma with dried fruits and honey.  The color is dark brownish red with an off white head with good lacing.  A bitter roasted malt flavor is balanced by a sweet dried fruit accent and mild yeasty cream like notes with a little bit of caramel.   A thick and creamy mouthfeel with average carbonation stretches into a bitter sweet aftertaste.  Very satisfying.

Bottle.  Vanilla/orange fruitcake aroma (initially had a wet wood/cardboard aroma that faded after setting for a few minutes.  Yellow-amber color with small but long lasting head.  Dried orange malt with strong citric hops finish - not cloying though.  A great sipping beer - in a class by itself - a doppel-alt.

Bottle: Pours a deep crimson mahogany color with a nice puffy white head and lots of lacing. The nose is very malty with lots of cherry, alcohol, fig, dark crusty bread and a hefty dose of molasses, honey and plum. The flavor is a bit sweet and chewy, lots of alcohol and a full bodied spicy malt mouthfeel. Bittersweet finish and a pleasing floral tail. Altbier? More like imperial!

rbsxg05, bottled. rich, deep shade of copper. big biscuity aroma plus tinned plums that have been left open in the tin for a few days in the fridge. rich, buttery alcohol, quite fruity with red berry and a light grassiness and decent bitterness. balanced and really tasty

Pours a clear maroon with little to no head.  Pretty unique smell with bread dough, dark fruits, malt, and orange.  Kind of bitter in the taste, slightly sweet.  Grapefruit, citrus, and malts.  Kind of wrecks the palate.  Not too bad, pretty interesting.
altbier?  pour hazy dark brown with little head, whiffs nutty aroma with a hint of chocolate.  heavy and bitter.

Muddy brown pour with bubbly tan head.  Wonderful aroma that is very complex with definite hints of raisins, sugar and malt.  Taste is similary complex with a beautiful alcohol flavor combined with a nutty, roasty aftertaste; the honey flavor is again evident, but nowhere near as strong as in the Sticke.    The hops definitely come through as well in the aftertaste.  Nice creamy palate; the Uerige products I have sampled to date cannot be compared to anything else I have tried in my short legal age lifetime...they are worth seeking out!

pours a gorgeous mahogany with a light tan head... which oh! so gracefully falls to a thin layer
Nose of raisins, plums, caramel, some smoke and a whiff of alcohol
Taste is incredibly variegated, licorice, dark figs, roast, smoke all with a nice big firm hop bite which is (black pepper like) spicy. the alcohol is very well hidden. 
The finish is long creamy, medium bodied and grrr... I cant put words here.. smoke, fruit and hop appear and disappear
Overall: Absotively and posolutely, a German interpretation of barley wine. At 8.5 % should be a sipper but it is so beguiling and inviting flavorful that damn it I seem to be headed to the inevitable bottom of the glass. A must try!...I wonder what would happen if all 3 barley wine styles are tasted side-by side... I am rating it high... I dont think there is a style for the sticke

Small pop-top brown bottle from Florians in Auburn.  Copper-red slightly murky translucent body with about a half an inch of off-white head that leavea fairly good lacing.  Nuttiness dominates the aroma with just a hint of black licorice or root beer quality to it.  Nut, caramel malt, roastiness all play big parts in the flavor with hints of black licorice, fruit, and smoke with a clean finish.  Some alcohol warming present, although alcohol flavor is almost non-existent (impressively).  A nice and surprising creamy mouthfeel.  Drinkable for the abv and body, but Id still approach this as a bit of a sipper.  Actually impressed with this one.  An impressive altbier and a damn good lager.

Pours an ever so slightly hazed copper color. Half the pour is beer, half the pour is foam. Good head retention (a little too good - I am getting impatient). Decent lacing. Sweet malty aroma - caramel and brown sugar.

The flavor is very similar to the aroma, but substantially more pronounced. Then there is this wonderfully bitter hop presence in the finish that makes you forget that this is a sweetish beer. Until the next sip, anyway. Ah - when the last sip is gone, that hop presence lingers a good long time. Fuller body, on the smoother side, and softly but very generously carbonated.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with hints of red, with a decent sized white head.  The aroma is extremely malty, with a hint of hops.  The flavor was very malty.  Sweet fruits, caramel, dates, raisons, with a touch of alcohol.  Very smooth and tasty.

11.2oz bottle.  Aroma:  Good sweet maltiness with a nice toffee note.  Alcohol and dark fruits seem to twine together in an aroma similar to rum raisin.  Some bready yeastiness and a bit of spiciness.  Appearance:  Poured a murky reddish brown.  Off-white head was small, creamy, and short lived.  Not much lacing.  Flavor:  Medium-sweet maltiness with some caramel and raisin.  Alcohol is noticeable but merges well with th rest of the beer.  Some light earthy hops into the finish.  Sweet but not cloying finish.  Medium-light bitterness.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Low carbonation.  Light alcohol warming in back of mouth. Overall:  Very barleywine-esque.  Lots of good malt flavors.  Low carbonation kept me from scoring this higher.

First of all, great looking bottle and nice touch with the resealable ceramic top. Pours a deep reddish brown that allows some light to pass through. Thick, creamy head. Aroma is malt, raisins, dates and caramel. These same qualities are also present in the flavor albeit a bit stronger than the aroma. Bitter finish but not excessive. The alcohol is noticeable but does not interfere with this beer. A nice choice for a winter evening.

This beer is mothers milk to me!

brought to me courtesy of brentk56...THANK YOU!

poured a beautiful deep amber/rust color into my HB stick.

The smell is rich with raisins, molasses, and sweeter malt.

The taste is all molasses, toffee, raisins, plum, and a little red apple.

mouthfeel is super creamy and smooth.

Fantastic beer. just absolutely awesome.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2007 now this is a beer.  Glorious dark ruby color with a frothy white head.  Aroma is very malty, caramelly.  Flavor is very rich and thick.  Glorious malt flavors,  not sure what beers Ive had that are as malty as this.  Some dark fruit flavors, too.  Its almost a barleywine without hops and without the nasty alcohol sting.  Thus, the bitterness is not as pronounced as the uerige alt, but there is still some bitterness on the finish.  If I could only find the Sticke I think it wouldbe the right balance of flavor without all the alcohol a la Goldilocks and the three bears.  Afterthought, wow this bastard has 75 ibus, but its blended well with the malt.
Nice hop aroma upfront, sligh citrus fades, with touchs of dark fruit.  Palate is full bodied alcohol is hardly noticable.  Nice winter-time drink though I prefer my barley-wines with a bit mor umph.

has a sweet beer-like aroma.

No kidding. Really does.

This beer is slightly on the bitter side, but not excessively so. 

Has a pleasant bitter-sweetness that is easy to sip and encourages a responsible and proper alcohol delivery pace.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2014 Prettily designed flip-top bottle (with many, many thanks to MoritzF !) : Amber coloured, firm creamy off-white head; cinnamon, liquorice in the sweet-fruity nose with hoppy edges - almost a perfest english aroma...; strong bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied; lingering bitter-sweet and fruity (a bit like cough syrup) finish. A great winter-warmer......und lecker, aber kein Dröppke !

Orange-brown with thick white froth.  Aroma of tons of malt, dark fruit, and spices.  Taste is similar, with a bit of citrus, some brown sugary/molasses sweetness and slight bitterness at the end.  Lighter than expected, well hidden alcohol and nice finish.

Pours dark brown / garnet with a good sized light tan rocky head.  The aroma is effervescent and fruity, fairly sharp, sweet malt and white grape - not at all what I was expecting.  Medium body with light soft carbonation.  The taste starts sharp, sweet, woody and traces of honey - quite cloying.  The alcohol is very noticable.  The finish has even more alcohol presence and lots of woody flavors.  This is interesting, but certainly not as good as I hoped for.

Creamy 1.5 finger tan head atop a dark brown pour.  Great lacing.  Wonderfully complex aroma.  Malty toasty sweetnees mixed with hoppy floral notes.  Medium bodied mouth feel.  Perfectly carbonated.  Toasty caramel sweet taste with a pleasing crisp bitter aferbite.  An excellent beer.

much much better than the alt

pretty much what everyone else here has for a description...  i was pleasantly surprised..

Pours wtih a deep red-brown body topped by a thick head with a good amount of lacing.  Its sweet and malty with a bitter, grassy and slightly piney hop note.  Much hoppier than I expected.  Full bodied, dry and warming.

11.2oz. bottle:  This bottle gives a new definition to the term "long neck".  This beer certainly has the longest, skinniest neck on a swing top that I have ever seen.  It opens with a loud pfffft.
